hi reddit i m not sure who else to turn to a i recently had to stop seeing my therapist because i moved state and she is only licensed in my previous state of residence i am looking for a new therapist but i simply can t keep this inside me anymore and i need a place to get it out this year and the last few month of 0 ha been the absolute worst of my entire life i can not believe the amount of negativity loss tragedy and pure bad luck that i ve been experiencing since fall of 0 it s been blow after blow and i can feel myself giving up i m giving up hope i m giving up my optimistic attitude i m giving up my will to continue existing in august of 0 my boyfriend of two year and i began our descent into what eventually led to our breakup in mid december we shared an apartment in oregon and i had to move out in january and move across the country back to my hometown in illinois i wa devastated about the breakup and under immense stress trying to find a moving company to haul my belonging such a long distance i finally found one and it turned out to be a scam they stole all my belonging and i m in the middle of several complaint with them but still have yet to see my thing and i don t think i ever will i lost my boyfriend and my life s worth of item at the same time living back at home ha been difficult a my sister life here and we do not have the best relationship she is severely mentally ill with addiction depression and borderline personality disorder so it s been very hard trying to manage her mood outburst destruction etc she ha attacked me many time said countless hurtful thing and done endless physical damage to the house living with her is very stressful on top of all this my grandpa just died tonight i got a call from my brother out of the blue i can t process this right now and i m at my wit end in the past month i ve lost my boyfriend whom i still love my old apartment and old life in oregon all of my life s worth of belonging and now my grandpa it s almost funny how insanely negative this year ha been i simply can not see myself recovering from all this loss and sadness and i don t know what to do it is just too much and i have no hope or light left i m feeling suicidal

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you have been through an incredibly difficult and challenging time this year, and I can understand how overwhelming it must feel. It's important to acknowledge that you are not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to help yourself during this difficult period.

Firstly, it may be helpful to reach out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, and share what you're going through. Sometimes just expressing our feelings can provide some relief and support. Additionally, consider seeking comfort and understanding from online communities or support groups where you can connect with others who have experienced similar losses and hardships.

In terms of managing your emotions and coping with these multiple losses, it might be beneficial to explore different strategies that work for you. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of purpose can be helpful. This could include hobbies, creative outlets, exercise, or even finding ways to help others who may be going through difficult times as well.

Taking care of your physical health is also crucial during times of emotional distress. Make sure you are getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular physical activity. These self-care practices can positively impact your mental well-being and overall resilience.

When it comes to dealing with the loss of material possessions and the breakup of a relationship, it's important to remember that grieving is a natural part of the healing process. Allow yourself to feel the pain and sadness associated with these losses, but also try to focus on what you have gained from these experiences. It may be helpful to reframe your perspective and find gratitude in the lessons learned or opportunities for personal growth that have emerged.

Regarding your difficult living situation with your sister, it may be worth considering having an open and honest conversation with her about how her behavior is affecting you. Setting boundaries and establishing clear expectations regarding her mood outbursts and destructive behavior can help create a more harmonious living environment. If necessary, you may also want to consider seeking advice or support from a social worker or counselor who specializes in helping individuals navigate challenging family dynamics.

Lastly, it's important to address the recent loss of your grandpa. Grief is a complex and individual process, so allow yourself to grieve in your own way and at your own pace. Seeking support from friends, family, or even a grief support group can provide you with a safe space to share your feelings and memories. Additionally, exploring healthy ways to honor and remember your grandpa, such as creating a photo album or writing letters, can be therapeutic.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to not have all the answers right now. Be patient with yourself and prioritize self-care as you navigate through this difficult period. If you find that your feelings of hopelessness and suicidal thoughts persist, it's important to reach out to a helpline or crisis center in your area for immediate assistance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

want to communicate in my first job my second job no one speaks english like literally the entire store is all people from another country it s kind of ridiculous because training is non existent i literally would be standing around if it wasn t for me having past experience working in the same kind of field the employee turnover is ridiculous and the supervisor when they can communicate to me only complain about how they are only working there so because of their visa but once they are full citizen they leave the hour go by so long and working in complete silence frustrating to the point where i had to start wearing earphone while i work and listen to music anyways after typing all of this i know i won t read it over so sorry for any mistake or thing that aren t clear i think honestly i m just too pessimistic and making excuse for myself but this feeling i have in me and the way everything in life is just so upsetting the breakdown and all the fucking cry like i m so over it and i just want to either be content or at least have some kind of method to get through all of this i m so exhausted and i feel like i keep getting the short end of the stick every time

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I can understand how overwhelming and frustrating that must be. It's great that you've reached out for support, even if it's just to vent.

First of all, I want to acknowledge the courage it takes to share your experiences. It's not easy opening up about personal struggles, and I appreciate your willingness to do so. While I may not have all the answers, I'm here to offer guidance and support as best I can.

Based on what you've shared, it seems like your depression has been affecting multiple areas of your life, causing you to lose motivation and interest in things that used to bring you joy. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to start finding some relief.

One strategy that might be helpful is to focus on self-care. This involves taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally. Start by identifying activities or hobbies that you used to enjoy before your depression took hold. Even if you don't feel motivated, try engaging in those activities again, even if it's just for a short period of time each day. You might find that they help lift your mood and provide a sense of purpose.

Additionally, reaching out for support from friends, family, or a support group can make a big difference. Sometimes talking about our struggles with people who genuinely care can provide comfort and perspective. Don't hesitate to lean on those around you when you need them.

Regarding your living situation, I can see how the renovations must be adding to your stress. While it may not be an immediate solution, creating a calm and peaceful space for yourself can have a positive impact on your mental well-being. Consider investing in items that make your apartment feel more comfortable and soothing, such as a good mattress, blankets, or decorations that bring you joy.

When it comes to your parents, it's clear that your relationship with them has been challenging. It's important to set boundaries and prioritize your own well-being. If being around toxicity triggers your depression, consider limiting contact with your parents or finding healthy ways to cope with their negativity, such as practicing mindfulness or engaging in activities that bring you joy.

Regarding your feelings of pessimism and making excuses, it's understandable that you're feeling this way given your circumstances. However, it may be beneficial to challenge those negative thoughts and beliefs. Instead of focusing on what's wrong or what you can't control, try shifting your perspective to what you can do and what you're grateful for. This shift in mindset can help you regain a sense of control and optimism.

Lastly, seeking professional help from a mental health expert or therapist can provide you with the tools and strategies tailored to your specific needs. They can guide you through this journey and help you develop coping mechanisms that work for you.

Remember, recovery takes time and effort, but it is possible. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and with the right support and resources, you can find your way back to a place of contentment.

Take care of yourself and keep reaching out for support when you need it.

existential crisis and angst ha become a month period drama for me every few month i will come across or think of a existential or scary thought where i ll go down a large rabbit hole and in the end become a nervous and terrified wreck i ve been through a existential crisis on mind philosophy sexuality identity apocalypse anxiety biology philosophy space anxiety and now it look like the next one will be quantum fucking physic based if i don t stop it in time i m just so sick of this cycle of fucking misery throughout my life i can t find any happiness or calmness because of my year is spent being terrified and super anxious sometimes i feel like lying down and cry but this depression ha made me so numb i can t cry anymore i just can t fucking take this anymore

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking support from trusted friends or loved ones who can provide a listening ear and understanding during these difficult times. Sharing your thoughts and feelings with someone you trust can help alleviate some of the burden you're carrying.

Additionally, exploring relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness, or meditation may be beneficial for managing your anxiety. These practices can help ground you in the present moment and reduce the intensity of anxious thoughts.

Engaging in activities that bring you joy and a sense of purpose can also be helpful. Pursuing hobbies, creative outlets, or meaningful projects can provide a positive focus and distraction from existential worries. Engaging in activities that promote a sense of accomplishment and fulfillment can contribute to an overall sense of well-being.

Another suggestion is to try challenging your negative thoughts and fears through cognitive restructuring. This involves examining the evidence for and against your anxious thoughts and developing more balanced and realistic perspectives. It can be helpful to keep a journal where you write down your anxious thoughts and then analyze them objectively.

Lastly, if you find that your existential crisis and anxiety continue to significantly impact your daily life and well-being, it may be worth considering reaching out to a mental health professional. They can provide guidance, support, and evidence-based interventions tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, it's important to take care of yourself and prioritize self-compassion throughout this process. Change takes time, and it's okay to seek help and support along the way.

[Question]
on the surface i can think of a lot of reason feeling ashamed about needing med worrying about side effect forgetting about them etc but at the end of the day i can t say exactly why i just know i don t want to take my med at the same time i know i need them i know that without them i simple task like showering and doing dish feel impossible i ll fall behind on my schoolwork isolated myself and sleep hour a day i know they work for me and that i ve felt much better when i wa taking them regularly but dang it i just don t want to take them one day i just ignored my alarm to take them and then i ve kept doing it now i take them so sporadically that they can t be doing much they re an ssri and mood stabilizer so they need to build up in your system and such part of me think maybe i just hate the daily reminder that i m not ok like i think that maybe if i ignore it for long enough i ll forget that i feel that way but even knowing that may be a part of it it doesn t feel like that s all there is to it and i don t know what to do about it mostly i m just wondering if anyone else feel like this too and if you do do you know why you feel that way and what may have helped you get back on track with taking them regularly i ve talked to my therapist and friend but i haven t been able to really figure out the full reason i feel this way or how to get back to taking them regularly if you ve dealt with this before or think you may understand why this resistance to taking med is happening i d appreciate hearing some potential reason or way to improve this of course everyone s mental health is unique so i may not relate to someone else s reason but i would still really appreciate hearing any potential one so i can understand my feeling about this a bit better

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of internal conflict regarding your medication. On the one hand, you recognize the benefits it brings and have experienced improvement when taking it regularly. However, on the other hand, you feel resistance and struggle with consistency.

One possible reason for this resistance could be related to the daily reminder that you need medication to manage your symptoms. It's not uncommon for individuals to have a desire to forget or ignore the reality of their condition. Ignoring the alarm to take your meds might be a way of avoiding that reminder. 

To address this, it may be helpful to explore alternative strategies that can serve as reminders without feeling like a constant reminder. For example, setting multiple alarms throughout the day or finding a routine that incorporates taking your medication into daily activities can make it easier to remember.

Additionally, it's important to consider the potential reasons behind your resistance. You mentioned that you may hate the daily reminder because it serves as a constant reminder that you're not okay. It might be beneficial to acknowledge and validate these feelings rather than suppressing them. Exploring coping mechanisms such as journaling, talking to a trusted friend, or engaging in self-care activities that bring you comfort can help you process and manage these emotions.

Another aspect to consider is building accountability and support systems around your medication routine. Sharing your struggle with friends or loved ones who understand and can provide encouragement may be helpful. Additionally, creating a system where someone close to you ensures you take your medication daily can add an extra layer of accountability.

Lastly, it's essential to communicate openly with your therapist about your concerns and struggles with medication adherence. They can work with you to develop personalized strategies and techniques to improve consistency. Remember, therapists are there to support you through challenges and offer guidance tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, finding what works best for you may take time and experimentation. Be patient with yourself throughout this process and celebrate small victories along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i now think about suicide constantly i feel like it is my only option in the long term i will never finish school and be able to hold down a job i will never be able to be stable enough to give my wife child i can t live up to anything anyone expects of me i am stuck though my death would be a catastrophe in my wife s life and my brother s life and i have a few friend who would be devastated a well also and i really hate to say this but the biggest reason i can t is because i can t leave my dog with anyone else he is very attached to me and no one else and would be very unhappy without me so i am stuck i can t function despite 0 year of trying medication and therapy i have no will to live except not to hurt people around me i hate this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and share what you're feeling. I'm here to offer some guidance and suggestions for you to consider.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the emotions you're experiencing. Feeling like there's no way out may be overwhelming, but remember that there are always options and support available to you. It might be helpful to explore these feelings in more detail with someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member who can provide emotional support.

Regarding your concerns about being stuck in your current situation, it's understandable that you may feel trapped. However, it's worth considering that many people face challenges and setbacks in life and go on to achieve their goals. Have you thought about reaching out to a career counselor or vocational trainer who could help you develop skills and find alternative paths? Exploring different options might open up new possibilities for you.

When it comes to starting a family, it's essential to remember that parenthood is not solely determined by biology. Adoption and fostering are meaningful ways to create a family. While it may require additional steps and considerations, speaking with professionals in this field could provide valuable insights and resources to guide you towards parenthood.

Remember, seeking professional help is crucial. Therapists and counselors can assist you in developing coping strategies and exploring underlying issues contributing to your depressive symptoms. They can also help you set realistic goals and work on building a more positive mindset. Additionally, they may suggest medication as part of your treatment plan if appropriate.

In addition to professional help, self-care practices can make a difference. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies, exercise, spending time with loved ones, or practicing mindfulness techniques, can contribute to your overall well-being.

Lastly, don't hesitate to reach out to your support network. Sharing your struggles with trusted friends or family members can provide comfort and understanding. They may also be able to offer practical assistance or connect you with resources within their own networks.

Remember, change takes time, and healing is a process. It's important to be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, even if it may not feel like it right now. Keep reaching out for support, exploring new possibilities, and taking small steps towards a brighter future.

[Question]
no one will read this but there would be occasion i took benzodiazepine and alcohol together and had no memory for example mg ativan and a beer or beer and three ativan or beer and ativan i haven t done that in awhile issue is i am having extreme anxiety that i have ruined my brain chemical somehow like very bad and now i ve convinced myself i ve ruined my brain and i m going to be anxious forever

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling anxious about the potential effects of mixing benzodiazepines and alcohol on your brain. It's important to remember that everyone's experience can be different, and it may take time to determine the long-term effects of this combination. Here are some suggestions to help you cope with your anxiety:

1. Educate yourself: Research the effects of benzodiazepines and alcohol when taken together. Understanding the potential risks can help alleviate some of your concerns.

2. Seek support: Consider reaching out to trusted friends or loved ones who can provide emotional support during this time. Sharing your worries with someone you trust may help ease your anxiety.

3. Practice self-care: Engage in activities that promote relaxation and well-being, such as exercise, meditation, or hobbies you enjoy. Taking care of your physical and mental health is crucial.

4. Challenge negative thoughts: Recognize that your anxiety might be causing you to catastrophize the situation. Remind yourself that there is no definitive evidence suggesting that one instance of mixing benzodiazepines and alcohol will definitely ruin your brain.

5. Set realistic expectations: Understand that recovery from substance use is a process that varies for each individual. Give yourself time to heal and focus on making positive changes rather than expecting immediate results.

6. Create a routine: Establishing a daily routine can provide structure and stability, which can be helpful in managing anxiety. Include activities that promote self-care and healthy habits.

7. Consider therapy: If your anxiety persists or worsens, seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor might be beneficial. They can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, it's essential to approach your recovery journey with patience and compassion for yourself. While it's natural to have concerns, try not to let them consume your thoughts or interfere with your overall well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling afraid and uncertain about what the future holds. It takes a lot of courage to consider making a change, especially when it involves leaving behind what is familiar to you. While I can't provide a clear answer on how or when to make this transition, I can offer some guidance and suggestions to help you navigate this process.

Firstly, it's important to remember that change is a personal journey and there isn't a one-size-fits-all approach. Take the time to reflect on your own needs, values, and goals. Consider what factors are contributing to your feelings of being afraid and unhappy, and try to identify specific areas in your life that you would like to improve.

When it comes to religion, exploring your beliefs can be a deeply introspective experience. It might be helpful to research different religious practices and philosophies that resonate with you. Engaging in open-minded discussions with individuals who have had similar experiences may also provide valuable insights and perspectives.

In terms of the right time and way to make this transition, it's essential to prioritize your safety and well-being throughout the process. Surrounding yourself with supportive friends or family members who can offer emotional support during this time can be beneficial. Additionally, seeking out resources such as books, articles, podcasts, or online communities that discuss personal stories and experiences related to your situation can provide you with valuable information and advice.

Remember, taking small steps towards your desired change can be empowering. Start by exploring your interests and engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. Surround yourself with positive influences and create a routine that promotes self-care and personal growth.

Lastly, seeking professional guidance from a mental health expert or counselor who specializes in supporting individuals going through similar transitions may provide you with additional support and guidance tailored to your specific needs. They can help you develop coping strategies, manage any anxiety or fears you may have, and provide a safe space for you to express your concerns and explore your options.

Ultimately, the timing of such a transition is a deeply personal decision, and it's important to listen to your intuition and trust yourself as you move forward. You deserve relief and happiness, and by taking steps towards understanding and embracing your true self, you are on the path to finding just that.

i just fucking hate my self i m turning into a fucking loser i ve recently pushed my girlfriend away by being a fucking depressed loser i fucked it all up just by not trying hard enough and i hate myself for it she wa the only person who actually loved me and now she doesn t want to see me anymore i don t know why i m surprised how could i be able to maintain a serious relationship when i can t even show up to work on time i never thought i would ever find love but i did and i fucked it all up fucked up the only good thing i had in my life work suck life suck and i m just soooo fucking over it i m not cut out for the ups and down of life i m just not cut out for life in general i m a fucking lost depressed loser that at the end of the day ha nothing to be proud of tonight i really just want to kill myself and end this hell i don t think i can take this shit anymore man

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and share what you're feeling, so I commend you for that.

Firstly, it's important to remember that there is always hope, even in the darkest of times. While it may feel overwhelming right now, it doesn't mean that things will always be this way. You have the ability to make positive changes in your life, and with time and support, things can get better.

When it comes to hating yourself, it's crucial to challenge those negative thoughts. Remember that everyone makes mistakes and faces challenges in their lives. It doesn't define your worth as a person. Try to focus on your strengths and accomplishments, no matter how small they may seem. Celebrate those victories and remind yourself that you are capable of growth and change.

Regarding pushing your girlfriend away, it's understandable that you feel guilty and scared. Communication is key in any relationship, and it can be helpful to express your feelings and concerns to your partner. If you feel comfortable doing so, consider having an open and honest conversation with her about how you've been feeling. Sharing your struggles might help her understand what you're going through and provide an opportunity for her to offer support.

It's also important to take responsibility for your actions and learn from them. Reflect on what led to this situation and think about how you can prevent similar circumstances in the future. Identifying patterns or triggers that contribute to your depressive episodes can be a good starting point. Consider seeking professional help or joining a support group where you can learn coping strategies and receive guidance tailored to your specific needs.

In terms of maintaining a relationship, communication, understanding, and support from both partners are vital. However, it's also essential to recognize when it may be healthier to focus on individual growth and well-being. Sometimes, taking time apart can allow for personal reflection and the opportunity to address underlying issues. Use this time to work on yourself, develop new hobbies or interests, and focus on building a stronger foundation for a future relationship.

Regarding work and life in general, it's common to feel unfulfilled or dissatisfied at times. Exploring different career paths or finding meaning beyond work can be beneficial. Consider setting goals that align with your values and passions. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment outside of work can help create a more balanced and satisfying life.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. Seek support from trusted friends or family members who can provide a listening ear. Additionally, consider exploring self-help resources such as books, podcasts, or online communities that offer guidance and support.

Lastly, if you ever find yourself in a crisis or feel unable to keep yourself safe, reach out to a helpline or emergency services right away. There are people who genuinely care about you and want to help.

Take care of yourself, and remember that there is always hope for a brighter future.

i hate it i barely sleep on my weekend off day have to wake up early for work and i still feel tired usually everyday when i wake up for work i automatically have to go to the bathroom must be my anxiety because my off day i don t my work is great and i work by myself and see basically no one all 0 hour but still i won t be at home lol

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really challenging to feel tired and unable to sleep during your weekend off day, especially when you have to wake up early for work. It's understandable that this situation is frustrating for you.

One possible explanation for your difficulty sleeping could be related to your anxiety. Many people find that their minds tend to race with worries or thoughts when they first wake up in the morning. This can make it difficult to fall back asleep. Since you mentioned experiencing anxiety symptoms like feeling overwhelmed and having racing thoughts, it may be worth considering how these feelings could be impacting your sleep.

To address this issue, you might want to try implementing some relaxation techniques before bed. Engaging in activities such as deep breathing exercises, meditation, or even journaling can help calm your mind and prepare your body for sleep. Additionally, creating a soothing bedtime routine that includes turning off electronic devices at least an hour before bed and ensuring your sleeping environment is comfortable and conducive to restful sleep can also contribute to better sleep quality.

Another factor that may be contributing to your tiredness during the day is your lack of social interaction. Working by yourself and seeing no one can sometimes leave you feeling drained and emotionally exhausted. It might be helpful to schedule regular breaks throughout your workday to engage in activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of connection. This could include reaching out to friends or loved ones for a chat, participating in hobbies or interests that you enjoy, or even joining online communities or forums where you can interact with others who share similar interests.

Lastly, while it may seem counterintuitive, maintaining a consistent sleep schedule can actually improve your overall sleep quality. Try to establish a regular bedtime and wake-up time, even on weekends, to regulate your body's internal clock. This can help promote better sleep patterns and make it easier to fall asleep and wake up at the desired times.

Remember, everyone's sleep needs and preferences are unique, so it's important to find what works best for you. If these suggestions don't seem to alleviate your sleep difficulties or if you're concerned about your mental health, it may be beneficial to seek support from a healthcare professional who can provide personalized guidance and assistance.

i m losing my best friend one of my friend is about to kill himself another friend is lying to me i m done i can t hold on i just can t i m done i m just so done i m ready to die i ve been ready to die so i m about to write my note and pick a time and day and hopefully i won t be alive much longer

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through an incredibly difficult time right now, and I want you to know that you don't have to face this alone. It's important to reach out for support when we're feeling overwhelmed, and I'm here to offer you guidance and suggestions on what steps you can take.

Firstly, it's crucial to prioritize your mental health. If you're feeling like you're ready to die, it's essential to seek immediate help. Reach out to a trusted friend or family member who can provide support and be with you during this challenging time. Opening up to someone you trust about what you're going through can help alleviate some of the burden you're carrying.

Additionally, consider seeking professional help from a mental health expert or counselor. They can provide you with the necessary tools and strategies to cope with your emotions and develop healthier ways of dealing with stress. Remember, there are many resources available to you, such as hotlines, online therapy platforms, or community support services. Don't hesitate to explore these options and utilize them whenever needed.

When it comes to losing a best friend, it can be incredibly painful and may feel like the end of the world. It's important to acknowledge and process these emotions. Give yourself permission to grieve and understand that change can be difficult. While it may feel overwhelming now, remember that time can heal wounds and bring new perspectives. Consider engaging in self-care activities that promote relaxation and emotional well-being, such as practicing mindfulness, journaling, or engaging in hobbies that bring you joy.

Regarding your friend who is lying to you, betrayal can be incredibly hurtful and can make you question your trust. It's essential to remember that trust takes time to rebuild, and it's okay to feel angry and confused. Start by giving yourself space to process your emotions. Reflect on whether this betrayal aligns with your friend's values or if it could be an indication of external pressures affecting their behavior. Communication is key in resolving conflicts, so consider having an open and honest conversation with your friend about how their actions have affected you. Trust takes time to rebuild, and sometimes friendships can change dynamics. It may be helpful to evaluate whether this friendship is healthy for you in the long run.

Remember, reaching out for support is a sign of strength, not weakness. Don't hesitate to lean on your support network during this challenging time. You deserve to have people who care about you and want to help. Take things one step at a time, and remember that healing and positive change are possible.

You could try researching self-help techniques, journaling, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation.

3. Engage in physical activity: Regular exercise has been shown to have positive effects on mental health. Even if it's just taking short walks outside, finding ways to incorporate movement into your daily routine can boost your mood and overall well-being.

4. Seek support online: There are various online communities and forums where individuals facing similar challenges come together to share their experiences and offer support. Connecting with others who understand what you're going through can provide a sense of belonging and validation.

5. Consider alternative treatment options: While you mentioned that you're not interested in medication, there are other non-prescription treatment options you could explore. Some people find relief through acupuncture, herbal supplements, or engaging in creative outlets like art or music therapy.

6. Set realistic goals: Sometimes, the weight of our problems can feel overwhelming. It might be helpful to break down your challenges into smaller, manageable tasks. Setting achievable goals can give you a sense of purpose and accomplishment.

7. Practice self-care: Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating well, and engaging in activities that bring you pleasure and relaxation. This could include things like taking baths, reading a book, listening to music, or practicing self-compassion.

Remember, finding the right path to manage your depression may take time and experimentation. It's okay to try different strategies and see what works best for you. You deserve support and healing, so please don't hesitate to reach out for help when you feel ready.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of anxiety lately, particularly in situations that were previously manageable for you. It can be really overwhelming when your body reacts strongly to stress and makes it difficult to function normally. I'm here to offer some guidance and suggestions to help you manage your anxiety in these situations.

Firstly, it's important to remember that deep breathing exercises like box breathing may not always work for everyone. While they can be helpful for many people, our bodies respond differently to stressors depending on the situation. Instead of focusing on a specific technique, try paying attention to your breath in general. Take slow, deep breaths and focus on filling your lungs completely. This can help calm your nervous system and bring your heart rate back to a more normal state.

In addition to deep breathing, grounding techniques can also be beneficial. Grounding involves redirecting your attention to the present moment and engaging your senses. For example, you can try focusing on the sensation of your feet touching the ground or the texture of an object in your hand. This can help bring your focus away from anxious thoughts and back to the present.

Another strategy that might be helpful is to identify and challenge any negative thoughts or beliefs that may be contributing to your anxiety. Sometimes our minds create worst-case scenarios or catastrophize situations. Take a moment to question these thoughts and consider alternative possibilities. Remind yourself that anxiety often exaggerates the actual threat or danger present in a situation.

It's also important to prioritize self-care. Engaging in activities that you enjoy and that help you relax can be a great way to manage anxiety. Whether it's reading a book, taking a walk in nature, or practicing a hobby, finding time for yourself and doing something you love can provide relief from stress.

Lastly, seeking support from loved ones can make a big difference. Talking to someone you trust about your experiences and feelings can be comforting and reassuring. They may offer a different perspective or simply lend a listening ear.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and practice. It's important to be patient with yourself as you work through these techniques and find what works best for you. If you're open to it, discussing your experiences and any past traumas with your therapist may also be beneficial.

I hope these suggestions help you better manage your anxiety in stressful situations. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are resources available to support you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people experience moments of deep unhappiness and struggle to find meaning or joy in their lives. It's important to remember that seeking support is a sign of strength, and there are steps you can take to help yourself during these difficult times.

Firstly, it might be helpful to identify the specific aspects of your life that are causing you the most distress. Reflecting on what areas are lacking or bringing you pain can provide some clarity and direction for finding solutions. Consider keeping a journal to track your thoughts and emotions, as this can be a useful tool for self-reflection and identifying patterns.

In addition, reaching out to trusted friends or family members who can offer a listening ear and emotional support may be beneficial. Sharing your feelings with someone who cares about you can provide comfort and a sense of connection. If you feel comfortable, consider opening up to those close to you and expressing how you've been feeling.

Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can also be helpful. This could involve pursuing hobbies, exploring new interests, or revisiting old ones. Engaging in activities that make you happy can serve as a temporary distraction from negative thoughts and help improve your overall well-being.

Another suggestion is to consider seeking professional help from a mental health expert, counselor, or therapist. They can provide guidance, coping strategies, and a safe space to process your emotions. Therapy can offer valuable tools and techniques to navigate through this difficult period and work towards building a more fulfilling life.

Lastly, it's important to prioritize self-care. This includes getting enough sleep, eating well-balanced meals, and engaging in regular physical exercise. Taking care of your basic needs can have a positive impact on your mental health and overall well-being.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to ask for support. You deserve to live a happy and fulfilling life, and with the right support and resources, it is possible to find meaning and joy again.

 It sounds like you're feeling really sad and lonely, especially since you're an international student in a new country. It can be tough to navigate friendships when there are language and cultural barriers. It's great that you're seeking guidance on how to handle this situation.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that building friendships takes time and effort. It might be helpful for you to join clubs or activities at your university that align with your interests. This can provide opportunities to meet people who share similar hobbies or passions, which can make forging connections easier.

When it comes to communicating with others, it's essential to be open and honest about your feelings. However, it's equally important to respect the other person's boundaries. If she mentioned before that she needed space, it may be best to give her some time to sort things out. Stalking her social media profiles without her knowledge can create a sense of unease and may make her uncomfortable. It's crucial to trust her when she says she needs space and allow her the freedom to pursue her interests independently.

Regarding your message to her, it's clear that you're feeling remorseful and want to make amends. However, it's important to remember that not all situations can be salvaged or fixed with an apology. Sometimes, people part ways due to incompatibilities or unresolved issues. Accepting this reality can help you move forward.

To rebuild your self-esteem, consider focusing on self-care and personal growth. Engage in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. Explore new hobbies, practice self-compassion, and surround yourself with supportive individuals who appreciate and value you for who you are.

Remember, building meaningful connections takes time and patience. Don't be too hard on yourself if things don't work out immediately. Keep putting yourself out there, being genuine, and respecting others' boundaries. With time, you'll likely form lasting friendships.

[Question]
i m quitting my job today and i m a wreck this job ha great people but the work and the hour day most of the year ha pushed me deeper into my depression than i can help i feel like such a failure quitting such a prestigious job because i couldn t handle it my therapist is hyping me up and all of my friend and family are so supportive but i am so unsupportive of myself that all of it read false ha anyone quit their job before because of mental difficulty how do you get excited about new opportunity rather than feeling depressed about past challenge

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and struggling with your decision to quit your job. It takes a lot of courage to make such a change, especially when it involves leaving a prestigious position. Remember that your friends and family, as well as your therapist, are there to support you and offer encouragement.

To help shift your mindset from feeling unsupportive of yourself to being more positive about this new opportunity, it may be helpful to focus on a few key strategies:

1. Acknowledge and accept your feelings: Give yourself permission to feel the sadness, disappointment, or any other emotions that come up. It's natural to have mixed feelings about leaving something behind. Instead of fighting against these emotions, try to acknowledge them and allow yourself to grieve the loss.

2. Reframe your perspective: Challenge negative thoughts and beliefs by looking at the situation from a different angle. Instead of dwelling on what went wrong or feeling like a failure, remind yourself that you are taking proactive steps to prioritize your mental well-being. Emphasize the positive aspects of quitting this job, such as regaining control over your schedule, pursuing personal interests, or finding a work-life balance that suits you better.

3. Set realistic expectations: Understand that adjusting to a new opportunity can take time, and it's normal to feel a bit anxious or uncertain during this transition period. Be patient with yourself and allow room for growth and learning. Focus on small goals and achievements rather than putting pressure on yourself to immediately excel in your new endeavor.

4. Seek support: Continue leaning on your support system of friends, family, and therapist. Share your concerns and fears with them, and let them help uplift you. Engage in activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of community, such as joining clubs, volunteering, or pursuing hobbies that align with your interests.

5. Practice self-care: Prioritize your mental health by engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This could include exercise, meditation, spending time in nature, pursuing creative outlets, or practicing self-compassion. Taking care of yourself will help build resilience and positivity as you navigate this new chapter.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and there is no one-size-fits-all approach to handling these situations. It's okay to feel a range of emotions during this transition, but by focusing on these strategies, you can gradually shift your mindset towards excitement and hope for the future.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have severe anxiety and ocd and i avoided the dating scene until year ago because i honestly wanted to get over my fear and find someone i wa lucky to find a great partner and have been in a good solid relationship for six month yet somehow throughout this whole thing i ve secretly become an absolute wreck i m constantly worrying if this is the right relationship preoccupied with analyzing everything trapped in my thought and making myself utterly miserable ha anyone else experienced this like is this standard for u anxious folk or is this actually a huge red flag that dating or even this person just isn t for me thank you kindly for any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've found a supportive community where you can share your experiences and seek advice. Dealing with anxiety and OCD can indeed present challenges in relationships, but it doesn't necessarily mean that this is a red flag or that the relationship isn't right for you. It's important to remember that everyone's experiences are unique, and what matters most is how these thoughts and behaviors affect your overall well-being and happiness.

One suggestion I have is to focus on building awareness of your anxious thoughts and challenging their validity. When you catch yourself analyzing or worrying excessively, try to pause and ask yourself if there is evidence supporting those thoughts. Often, our anxieties create irrational fears and doubts that may not align with reality. By questioning these thoughts, you can start to develop a more balanced perspective.

Another helpful strategy could be practicing self-care and stress management techniques. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help alleviate some of the anxiety and distress you're experiencing. This might include things like exercise, mindfulness meditation, journaling, or pursuing hobbies that you find fulfilling.

Communication is also key in any relationship. Consider having open and honest conversations with your partner about your struggles. Sharing your concerns can foster understanding and empathy between both of you. Additionally, discussing your needs and boundaries regarding relationships may help create a solid foundation for mutual growth and support.

Lastly, seeking professional guidance from a therapist who specializes in anxiety and relationship issues could be beneficial. They can provide personalized strategies and coping mechanisms tailored to your specific situation. A therapist can also assist you in exploring any underlying factors contributing to your anxiety and offer support throughout your journey.

Remember, finding a healthy balance between managing your anxiety and enjoying your relationship is an ongoing process. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve to have a fulfilling relationship while still addressing your personal growth and well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

if it werent for him i would have been dead by now i cant imagine how horrible he would feel if i did it now im just in an eternal state of depression and cant do anything about it i both love him and hate him for it mostly love but god damn i feel trapped

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're in a really difficult and complex emotional situation. It's clear that this person has had a significant impact on your life, both positive and negative. Dealing with such intense emotions can be overwhelming, so it's important to remember that you don't have to face this alone.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge the bravery it took for you to reach out and express your feelings. It takes strength to confront our emotions and share them with others. While I may not have all the answers, I'm here to offer support and guidance as best I can.

Given the circumstances you've described, it's understandable that you're feeling trapped in a cycle of depression and unable to find a way forward. One suggestion I have is to consider seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor who can provide you with the tools and strategies to navigate through this challenging situation. They can assist you in finding healthier coping mechanisms and working towards healing and growth.

In addition to seeking professional help, it might also be beneficial to explore self-care practices that resonate with you. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and peace can help improve your overall well-being. This could include things like practicing mindfulness or meditation, pursuing hobbies or interests that make you feel alive, spending time in nature, or engaging in creative outlets such as writing or art.

Another suggestion is to focus on building a strong support network around you. Connecting with friends, family members, or support groups who understand and empathize with your experiences can provide a sense of belonging and comfort. Sharing your thoughts and feelings within a safe and non-judgmental space can be incredibly therapeutic and empowering.

Lastly, it's important to remember that healing takes time and patience. It's okay to not have all the answers right now. Be gentle with yourself throughout this process and celebrate small victories along the way. Remember that you deserve happiness and fulfillment, and with the right support and resources, you can work towards finding a path forward that allows you to thrive.

Please keep in mind that my suggestions are not a substitute for professional help, but rather tools and guidance to consider as you navigate your emotions. If at any point you feel overwhelmed or in crisis, please reach out to a helpline or emergency services for immediate assistance.

hi everyone it s my first time posting on this forum i m really in a bad spot wondering if my anxiety ruined my situationship and would love to talk it through with someone if anyone could message me i d really appreciate it here s a bit more color on the situation we were good friend started talking in december hooked up beginning of february got into a disagreement the next weekend at a bar because this girl who he had hooked up with previously wa all over him and it made me visibly very uncomfortable we spend the next week talking every day but not seeing each other i definitely try to initiate a few hangout so doe he but le so and it didn t really work i know he s also talking to other girl a well but continues to tell me that he really like me and just want to keep getting to know me better last saturday we hook up he again tell me how much he like me and that he doesnt want to play game thursday i ask him over snapchat if he want to meet up for st paddy and he doesnt answer we end up at the same bar i make a comment saying ohh i thought you said no game just teasing he get upset and think i m trying to have a feeling talk with him at a bar while he s drunk we flush it out over text the next day and i ask him if he want to hang out this weekend he say we ll see and that he ha some plan already we end up bumping into each other again on saturday this time we talk the whole afternoon but i can tell he s le flirty more withdrawn he s going to a concert so he leaf i tell him later we re all going out to this bar he like and he heart the message this morning i snap him and ask how the concert wa no response obviously i need to leave this man alone at least for a little bit but i feel like back the first time we hooked up he wa so so into me then i ruined it by being jealous at the bar and by continuing to only pursue him i got complete tunnel vision i should have just left him alone and maybe he would have come to me but now i ve put so much pressure on the situation it doesn t help that my roommate who is his friend tell me constantly how much he doesn t actually like me and that he s just a player

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're feeling really confused and unsure about your situation with this guy. It's understandable that you're questioning whether your anxiety ruined things between you two. The good news is that there are steps you can take to address these concerns and improve your situation.

First, it's important to communicate openly and honestly with the guy. You've already started doing this by discussing your feelings, which is great. However, try to create a safe space where both of you can express yourselves without judgment or blame. Active listening and empathy can go a long way in understanding each other's perspectives.

Additionally, consider taking a step back from the situation for a while to allow things to settle. Sometimes, giving people the space they need can help them gain clarity and make better decisions. This break can also give you an opportunity to focus on yourself and work on any personal issues that may be contributing to your anxiety.

During this time apart, try to engage in self-care activities that promote relaxation and reduce stress. This might include practicing mindfulness or meditation, engaging in hobbies you enjoy, or seeking support from friends and loved ones. Taking care of your mental well-being is crucial in managing anxiety.

When you feel ready, reach out to the guy again and check in with him. Ask how he's been and what he's been up to. Try to approach the conversation from a place of genuine interest rather than solely focusing on your relationship with him. By rebuilding the friendship first, you may be able to establish a stronger foundation for something more to develop naturally.

Lastly, remember that relationships should never be based solely on fear or anxiety. Trust and mutual feelings are essential for a healthy relationship to thrive. If you find that your anxiety continues to impact your ability to navigate this situation, it may be helpful to seek professional guidance from a therapist who can provide you with coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. While it can be challenging, taking these steps may help you regain clarity and potentially improve your situation.

seriously applying for job is hard enough for a stable person but when you have someone like me with no qualification no education no nothing applying for job is downright a soul crushing experience deep down i seriously don t even want the shitty as job anyway but i have to in order to survive then thinking about once i move out living alone in a crappy place working this meaningless job make me internally dieing i genuinely wish i wa never born into this era i don t belong here at all

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly challenging to navigate the job application process, especially when you feel like you don't have the qualifications or education that most positions require. It's understandable that this experience is soul-crushing for you. Remember that many people face similar struggles and it doesn't define your worth or potential.

Firstly, it might be helpful to focus on building a strong foundation for yourself. While formal education and qualifications can be valuable, they are not the only paths to success. Consider exploring alternative ways to gain skills and knowledge that align with your interests and passions. This could involve taking online courses, attending workshops, or seeking mentorship from individuals who work in fields that interest you. By investing in your personal growth, you may find opportunities that are a better fit for your abilities.

Additionally, networking can play a crucial role in finding employment. Connect with professionals in your desired industry through platforms like LinkedIn or professional groups. Attend industry events or meetups to expand your network and gain insights into potential career paths.  It sounds like you've been feeling depressed and disillusioned about the future for a long time now. It's understandable that you're feeling hopeless and questioning why things haven't gotten better for you.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that your feelings are valid and understandable given your experiences. It can be incredibly challenging to maintain hope and optimism when faced with continuous hardships. However, there are some steps you can take to improve your situation and find meaning in life despite the difficulties.

One approach is to focus on building a support system. Connecting with others who can empathize with your struggles can provide a sense of belonging and emotional support. Additionally, exploring new interests or hobbies can help bring joy and fulfillment into your life. Whether it's painting, gardening, playing an instrument, or any other activity that sparks your interest, finding moments of happiness and contentment can make a significant difference.

Additionally, taking care of your physical health can have a positive impact on your mental well-being. Firstly, I want to assure you that your feelings are valid. It's important to acknowledge and accept what you're experiencing rather than suppressing or dismissing it. While it may be difficult to find motivation or joy in life right now, there are steps you can take to start finding meaning again.

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking support from others. Connecting with friends, family, or even joining a support group can provide a sense of belonging and understanding. Sharing your thoughts and emotions with trusted individuals who care about you can offer comfort and encouragement during this difficult time.

Additionally, exploring new hobbies or revisiting old ones might be beneficial. Engaging in activities that align with your interests and values can help rekindle a sense of purpose and fulfillment. While it may feel challenging at first, trying out different activities could lead you to discover new sources of joy and satisfaction.

Another suggestion is to focus on self-care. Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial. This includes getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular exercise. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness meditation can help reduce stress and promote a sense of calm.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're feeling very isolated and struggling with the fear of being disliked or rejected by others. It's understandable that these feelings are causing you a lot of anxiety and making it difficult for you to fully enjoy life.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone has their own insecurities and fears when it comes to forming connections with others. You are not alone in feeling this way, and it can be helpful to remind yourself of that. Building friendships takes time and effort, and it's normal to feel nervous or unsure at times.

One suggestion I have is to focus on being kind to yourself. Instead of constantly questioning your worth or fearing rejection, try to practice self-compassion. Treat yourself with the same kindness and understanding that you would offer a close friend. This can help build your confidence and make it easier to engage with others.

Additionally, finding ways to manage your anxiety can be beneficial. It might be helpful to explore relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness meditation. These practices can help calm your mind and body, allowing you to approach social situations with a clearer mindset.

Another strategy could be to start small and gradually expose yourself to social settings. For example, instead of attending a large meetup, you could try meeting up with one or two people at a time. This way, you can ease into social interactions without feeling overwhelmed.

Lastly, consider seeking support from a trusted friend or family member who can provide emotional encouragement and guidance. Having someone to talk to about your experiences and feelings can make a big difference in your journey towards building meaningful connections.

Remember, building friendships takes time and patience. It's okay to experience setbacks or face challenges along the way. Keep trying different approaches, stay open-minded, and be gentle with yourself throughout the process.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's really important to reach out and express what you're going through, so I appreciate you sharing your feelings with me. It sounds like you've been experiencing intense emotional pain for the past two years, and it's taken a toll on various aspects of your life.

Firstly, I want to assure you that there is hope and support available to help you through this difficult time. While I can't provide professional counseling or therapy, I can offer some guidance and suggestions that may be helpful:

1. Reach out for support: Consider confiding in someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member who can provide a listening ear and emotional support. Sharing your struggles with others can alleviate the burden you've been carrying alone.

2. Seek professional help: If you haven't already, it might be beneficial to find a mental health professional who can provide you with the necessary tools and strategies to cope with your emotions effectively. They can also help you develop a personalized plan to improve your academic situation and overall well-being.

3. Explore coping mechanisms: It's great that you're open to exploring new ways to cope with your emotions. In addition to journaling, consider trying other activities that bring you joy or a sense of calm, such as engaging in hobbies, practicing mindfulness or meditation, exercising regularly, or connecting with nature.

4. Build a support network: Try reaching out to old friends or joining social groups where you can meet people who share similar interests or experiences. Building a supportive network can help combat feelings of isolation and loneliness.

5. Prioritize self-care: Taking care of yourself physically, mentally, and emotionally is crucial. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that promote relaxation and self-reflection.

6. Set realistic goals: Break down your tasks and responsibilities into smaller, manageable steps. This can help reduce overwhelming feelings and allow you to focus on one thing at a time, increasing your chances of success.

7. Challenge negative thoughts: Recognize that your current situation may be clouding your perspective and leading to negative self-talk. Practice reframing negative thoughts into more positive and realistic ones. Remember, setbacks are temporary, and with time and effort, things can improve.

8. Consider seeking academic support: If your struggles with motivation and hope are primarily related to your academic performance, it might be helpful to seek guidance from a tutor or academic advisor who can provide you with strategies to improve your study skills and time management.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it may take time to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and by reaching out for support and actively working towards positive change, you can find hope and purpose in your life again.

i always have these time where i really think about myself in middle school and i get really fuckign sad i wa bullied and treated like shit but i never really admitted to it and wa always in denial about it i never really defended myself or stood up for myself and i wa really quiet and it make me want to slit my throat like i wish i just stood up for myself and defended myself and wasn t such a coward like i can t stop thinking about it and it really fuck up my mood and i always feel so shitty about everything like it s in the past and i can t do anything about it but i can t help but move on and it s constantly in the back of my mind it literally make my blood boil for some reason i have anger issue and when i get treated shitty for no reason especially when i m really quiet and shy it make me so fucking angry like why do u feel the need to pick on someone who s so introverted and clearly not very social like fuck you fuck them all and fuck every person who ever treated me like fucking shit in middle school elemantry school i hope they fucking burn espically this one kid named nick he made my life literal torture and the worst part wa that he wa in every one of my class fuck him and i will always wish nothing but the worst on him

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly difficult to revisit painful experiences from our past, especially when we feel like we didn't handle them the way we wish we could have. It sounds like your time in middle school was really challenging for you, and it's understandable that you're feeling a deep sense of sadness and anger about how you were treated.

One important thing to remember is that it's completely normal to have these feelings resurface from time to time. It can be helpful to create a safe space for yourself where you can allow these emotions to surface and express them in healthy ways. Writing in a journal, engaging in creative activities, or talking to a trusted friend are all potential outlets for processing these emotions.

While we can't change what happened in the past, we can choose how we respond to those experiences now. It might be beneficial to focus on self-compassion and forgiveness. Acknowledge that you were a different person at that time, and try to replace self-blame with self-acceptance. Remember that everyone has their own struggles and challenges, and it doesn't serve you to hold onto resentment or bitterness.

Building self-confidence can also be an important part of healing. Consider pursuing activities or hobbies that allow you to explore your strengths and passions. Engaging in positive experiences can help counterbalance the negative emotions associated with your past. Surrounding yourself with supportive and understanding people who appreciate you for who you are can also boost your self-esteem.

If anger continues to be a struggle for you, finding healthy ways to manage and channel it can be helpful. Engaging in regular exercise, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or meditation, and seeking support from friends or loved ones can all contribute to managing anger effectively.

Lastly, consider seeking professional support if you find that these feelings persist and significantly impact your daily life. A mental health therapist can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs and help you work through these experiences in a supportive and non-judgmental environment.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's a journey unique to each individual. Be patient with yourself and focus on self-care as you navigate this process.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and frustrated with your anxiety and job search. It's understandable that the anticipation of job interviews can trigger your anxiety, especially if past experiences have been difficult for you. Remember to take care of yourself during this time and practice self-care techniques that help you manage your anxiety.

Regarding your concerns about working in a kitchen, it's important to consider what truly aligns with your interests and values. While it may be discouraging to hear negative experiences from others, it's essential to find out for yourself what working in a kitchen is like. Consider reaching out to people who work in the food industry and asking them about their experiences. This way, you can gain a more balanced perspective and make an informed decision.

When it comes to finding a job, it's common to have worries and doubts. Remember that building confidence takes time and practice. One suggestion is to consider finding a support group or community where you can connect with others who may have similar experiences. Additionally, exploring creative outlets such as writing, painting, or journaling can be a way to process your emotions without having to share them directly. Expressing your feelings through these mediums can often bring relief and allow you to better understand yourself.

[Question]
i m f currently on a work trip with a few of my coworkers most of whom i ve known for year but haven t seen in person since covid started i m decently close with one person in particular and the rest i just have a normal professional relationship with last night everyone went out to celebrate a big milestone during the trip and had a great time i wa definitely pretty drunk by the end of the night and getting home is a little hazy but i woke up with good memory of the night before and wasn t concerned that anything had happened anyways no one had texted me this morning and i wasn t sure what the plan for the day wa so i reached out to the coworker i m closer with and asked what she wa up to she said she wa going to breakfast with another person on the trip and that i could come which i agreed to but then she texted and said they were actually leaving right now for breakfast and that we could meet up later this seemed odd to me since we re all in the same hotel and i could have been ready to head out whenever but it felt like she didn t want me to come i think i m reading into it a bit too much but now i m freaking out worried that i did something wrong last night and that s the reason i m not being invited along today i don t really have a track record of doing thing out of character while drunk though so i m just really confused and anxious tldr got drunk with coworkers who i haven t seen in a while and now it feel like no one want to hang out with me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Hey there,

I can imagine how awkward and confusing this situation must be for you. It sounds like you had a great time celebrating the milestone with your coworkers, and it's understandable that you're feeling a bit concerned now.

First of all, it's important to remember that assumptions are often not the best way to interpret situations. While it may seem like you did something wrong, it's more likely that there are other factors at play. Your coworkers might simply have their own plans for the day, or they may have assumed that you'd rather spend the day resting after a night of drinking.

To ease your mind, I suggest reaching out to your coworkers directly and asking them what's going on. Open communication is key in situations like these, and it's better to clear up any misunderstandings rather than dwell on them. You could send a group message or individual messages to ask about the day's plans and express your interest in joining.

Additionally, try not to read too much into people's actions if they don't explicitly communicate with you. Sometimes, plans change unexpectedly, or people might assume that you're not interested in participating. If you feel like you're being excluded, it's important to express your feelings and concerns in a calm and non-confrontational manner.

Remember, building relationships takes time and effort, and it's normal to experience ups and downs along the way. Don't be too hard on yourself and keep putting yourself out there. Engage in activities that align with your interests, whether it's joining group outings or initiating conversations with your coworkers.

Lastly, take care of yourself and prioritize self-care. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help boost your confidence and overall well-being. Whether it's reading a book, going for a walk, or practicing a hobby, finding moments of peace and enjoyment can help reduce anxiety and provide a sense of fulfillment.

I hope these suggestions help you navigate through this situation and feel more at ease. Remember, building connections takes time, so don't be discouraged by setbacks. Keep putting yourself out there, and I'm confident that you'll find a sense of belonging within your coworkers.

Take care, and have a great day!
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
im seriously so stuck i developed a horrible case of health anxiety and constantly think something is wrong with my brain or heart i ve been to the er twice now with everything coming back normal i feel bed ridden most day if im up and moving around for too long i feel extremely dizzy due to my tension headache i have high blood pressure and am on medication but i constantly think it s hurting my heart im only year old and i shouldn t be this concerned about my health i m so over feeling this way and every day get worse and worse i feel like i can t do anything but lay down i get sharp pain along my chest due to costochondritis and im always thinking it s the end my breathing is always fine and my heart never beat super rapidly so that make me feel better but the dizziness is unbearable i tried antidepressant and all they did wa make my anxiety worse and my heart beat abnormally fast anytime i stood up my doctor took me off of them and is more focused on my blood pressure im so scared of dying and i m so sick of feeling like this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now with your health anxiety. It can be incredibly overwhelming and exhausting to constantly worry about something being wrong with your brain or heart, especially when you've already been to the ER and had everything come back normal.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that your symptoms may be related to your anxiety rather than any physical issue. Anxiety can manifest in various physical sensations such as dizziness, tension headaches, and even increased heart rate. While it's important to take care of your physical health, it might be helpful to explore how your anxiety could be contributing to these symptoms.

One strategy that might be beneficial for you is practicing relaxation techniques or mindfulness exercises. These techniques can help you focus on the present moment and reduce anxious thoughts. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and guided imagery are all examples of relaxation techniques that you can try.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms to manage your anxiety can make a big difference. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of calm can help distract you from anxious thoughts. This could include hobbies, spending time with loved ones, or pursuing creative outlets.

It's also crucial to challenge negative thoughts that may be fueling your anxiety. When you catch yourself thinking something is wrong with your brain or heart, try to question the evidence behind those thoughts. Are there any objective facts supporting your fears? Often, our anxieties tend to exaggerate the likelihood of something being seriously wrong.

In terms of your treatment options, it seems like you've had a difficult experience with antidepressants. It's important to remember that not all medications work for everyone, and it may be worth exploring other options. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a type of therapy that focuses on identifying and challenging unhelpful thoughts and behaviors. It has shown great effectiveness in treating anxiety and may be something to consider discussing with a mental health professional.

Lastly, it's essential to prioritize self-care. Taking care of your physical and emotional well-being can greatly impact your overall mental health. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular exercise. Additionally, finding ways to relax and unwind, such as taking baths, reading, or listening to calming music, can provide much-needed relief.

Remember, overcoming health anxiety takes time and patience. It's important to be kind to yourself throughout this process. If you find that your symptoms are significantly impacting your daily life, it may be helpful to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
