[Question]
i m not sure if i have anxiety or adhd or im just introverted and procrastinating lol i started biting my nail since i wa a kid i tried hard to get rid of this habit but it not something i can control i put on nail polish usually but once it fall ill start biting them or fixing them with nail clipper a little bit of unsmoothness on my nail will bother me a lot and ill just sit there and keep fixing it for hour straight instead of doing any work literally every 0 min i would find somewhere bothering me on my nail i also overthink a lot it might be influenced by my mom who kept telling me that others might think negatively about me bc of any barely noticeable detail about what i do how i look so now i will just replay some scenario in my head hundred of time feel bad about myself and had to take deep breath say to myself it ok out loud or make some sudden noise to make my mind jump out of that vicious loop recently i feel that my attention span is getting even shorter i will sit down for work and get distracted after min and start watching youtube video for hour i notice myself doing that and i would think maybe i should go back to work but the other part of my mind is like numb and fail to take any action to the point that im only able to focus for a long time under pressure like a day before meeting or exam idk if it is just bad work ethic procrastination introversion or i should get a check up for anxiety adhd like i heard other ppl relate to me on point amp so idk if it just some common problem that i can just work it out either way can anyone give me any advice on whether to get a diagnosis or smth i could do on my own to mitigate these behavior thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out and seeking guidance! It can be challenging to determine if you have anxiety, ADHD, or are just introverted and procrastinating, but I'm here to offer some suggestions.

Firstly, let's address your nail-biting habit. It's common for many people to struggle with this habit, and it can be difficult to completely eliminate it. Instead of focusing on control, try redirecting your attention when you feel the urge to bite your nails. Engaging in activities like painting your nails, applying hand cream, or playing with stress balls can help occupy your hands and mind. Additionally, keeping a small notebook and pen nearby to jot down your thoughts or worries can also be helpful.

Regarding your concerns about overthinking, it's important to acknowledge that negative self-judgment can be influenced by external factors, such as your mom's comments. However, it's also crucial to challenge those negative thoughts and practice self-compassion. Whenever you catch yourself replaying scenarios in your head, try to remind yourself that nobody is perfect, and focus on the positive aspects of yourself and your actions. Journaling your thoughts and practicing mindfulness exercises, such as deep breathing and grounding techniques, can also assist in managing racing thoughts.

In terms of your shortened attention span, it's not uncommon for individuals to experience fluctuations in focus throughout their lives. While there are strategies to improve attention, it's essential to address potential underlying causes, such as stress or lack of sleep, which may contribute to your difficulties focusing. Establishing a structured routine, breaking tasks into smaller, manageable steps, and creating a conducive work environment can enhance your ability to concentrate. Regular exercise, adequate sleep, and a balanced diet can also positively impact your overall well-being and cognitive functioning.

As for whether to get a diagnosis or not, it can be beneficial to consult with a healthcare professional who can provide a comprehensive evaluation. They can assess your symptoms, identify any underlying conditions, and offer personalized advice. Remember, seeking a diagnosis doesn't mean you have a mental health disorder; rather, it can help guide you in understanding your experiences better and finding appropriate coping strategies.

Lastly, managing stress is crucial for overall well-being. In addition to practicing mindfulness exercises, consider incorporating relaxation techniques into your daily routine. This may include deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or engaging in hobbies that bring you joy and help you unwind. Setting realistic goals and prioritizing self-care can also contribute to reducing stress levels.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to be patient with yourself as you explore different strategies and coping mechanisms. You're taking a positive step by seeking advice, and I believe that with time and effort, you can find ways to manage these behaviors effectively.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have these bad episode of anxiety that last for day where i m constantly dissociated and whenever i try to sleep i wake up almost every hour with my body completely numb and my vision is like zoomed out and everything is super disoriented and weird i m so tired but i can t sleep and it keep me up all night and i m so exhausted i just want at least one good night rest but i can t even get that i feel like anxiety and dissociation are constantly kicking me around and i can never catch a break in life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time with these episodes of anxiety and dissociation that are affecting your sleep. It can be incredibly frustrating and exhausting to not be able to find relief, especially when it feels like they're happening constantly.

One suggestion I have is to establish a bedtime routine that promotes relaxation and creates a calm environment for sleep. This could include activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing deep breathing exercises before bed. Creating a peaceful atmosphere in your bedroom, with dim lighting and a comfortable sleep environment, may also help signal to your body that it's time to wind down and relax.

Additionally, finding ways to manage your anxiety throughout the day might alleviate some of the symptoms at night. Engaging in regular physical exercise, like going for walks or trying out yoga, can release tension and boost mood. Exploring stress-reduction techniques, such as mindfulness or meditation, may also provide some relief.

Another suggestion is to ensure you are prioritizing self-care. Sometimes when we're under a lot of stress, it can be easy to neglect our own needs. Taking breaks during the day to engage in activities you enjoy, connecting with loved ones, and making time for hobbies or interests can all contribute to overall well-being and potentially reduce the impact of anxiety on your daily life.

While these suggestions may not completely eliminate your experiences with anxiety and dissociation, they may help create a sense of balance and provide some relief. Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so it's important to find what works best for you. If these strategies don't seem to make a significant difference, seeking support from a mental health professional who can tailor treatment options specifically to your needs may be beneficial.

 It sounds like you've been through a lot and are dealing with a lot of pain and loneliness. It's understandable that you might feel forgotten and unimportant in the grand scheme of things. However, it's important to remember that each person's life is unique and valuable, and everyone has their own story to tell.

One suggestion I have is to focus on self-care and finding ways to nurture yourself. This could involve exploring activities or hobbies that bring you joy or a sense of fulfillment. Engaging in creative outlets such as writing or art can be a way to express yourself and process your emotions. Additionally, practicing mindfulness or meditation techniques may help you ground yourself in the present moment and find peace within yourself.

Another suggestion is to reach out and connect with others. Building meaningful connections can be challenging, but it's worth putting yourself out there. Consider joining social or community groups where you can meet people who share similar interests or experiences. Volunteering for causes you care about can also provide opportunities to connect with like-minded individuals. Remember, building relationships takes time and effort, but it's worth investing in.

Lastly, seeking support from a trusted friend or loved one can make a big difference. Opening up about your feelings and experiences to someone you trust can provide emotional validation and comfort. Sometimes, just having someone to listen without judgment can be incredibly healing.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to seek professional help if needed. A therapist or counselor can offer guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can assist you in navigating through your past traumas and developing healthier coping mechanisms.

You are deserving of love and happiness, even though it may not feel like it right now. Keep exploring different paths towards self-discovery and growth, and remember that your story is still being written.

[Question]
i m not a big fan of sharing overly personal stuff online so i ll just say that i ll have to take a moderately long plane ride soon a couple week from now i think and every day i have at least one mini panic attack worrying about it there are some minor complication that could happen to me on the flight but nothing particularly harmful or super bad in any sense i m mostly concerned about anxiety claustrophobia and the side effect of that while on the flight this is stressful and feel pointless a i know from past experience i never know how i ll feel until i m there or in this case in the anxiety inducing situation any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's completely understandable that you're feeling anxious about your upcoming plane ride. It can be overwhelming to worry about potential complications and deal with anxiety, claustrophobia, and the physical sensations they bring. Here are a few suggestions that might help:

1. Preparation is key: Before your flight, make sure you're well-prepared. Research the airport and flight procedures to know what to expect. Pack your carry-on bag wisely, including items that can help you relax during the flight like a book, music, or a puzzle.

2. Deep breathing exercises: Practice deep breathing techniques to help manage your anxiety. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and exhale slowly through your mouth. Focus on your breath and try to let go of any worries or fears.

3. Distraction techniques: Engage in activities that distract your mind from anxious thoughts during the flight. Listen to calming music, watch a movie, read a book, or do puzzles. Keeping your mind occupied can help reduce anxiety levels.

4. Seek support: Consider reaching out to friends or loved ones who can provide emotional support during this time. Talking about your concerns with someone you trust can be helpful. They may even have suggestions based on their own experiences.

5. Prioritize self-care: Take care of yourself physically and mentally leading up to the flight. Get enough sleep, eat nutritious meals, and engage in regular exercise. These practices can contribute to overall well-being and help manage anxiety.

6. Cognitive reframing: Challenge negative thoughts and replace them with more positive and realistic ones. Remind yourself that flying is statistically safe and focus on the enjoyable aspects of reaching your destination.

7. Consider medication or prescription: If your anxiety is significantly impacting your daily life and you feel it's necessary, consult with a healthcare professional about medication options. They can provide guidance and ensure you have appropriate support during the flight.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it's important to find coping strategies that work best for you. While these suggestions may help, if your anxiety persists or worsens, consider seeking professional guidance from a mental health expert who can provide personalized support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It's important to acknowledge the pain and distress you're experiencing. It can be incredibly difficult when you feel like no one is there to support you or understand what you've been through. While I can't provide professional advice, I can offer some suggestions that may help:

1. Reach out for support: Consider confiding in someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. Sharing your feelings with someone who cares about you can provide comfort and emotional support.

2. Seek counseling or therapy: Speaking with a mental health professional can offer valuable guidance and coping strategies tailored to your specific situation. They can help you process your experiences and emotions, and provide a safe space for you to express yourself without judgment.

3. Engage in self-care activities: Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies, exercise, or spending time in nature, can help alleviate some of the loneliness and pain you're feeling.

4. Connect with support groups: Consider joining a support group where you can meet others who have had similar experiences. Sharing stories and connecting with people who understand your struggles can create a sense of belonging and reduce feelings of isolation.

5. Explore community resources: Look into local organizations or charities that offer assistance or programs aimed at helping those who have experienced trauma or are feeling isolated. These resources can provide additional support and opportunities for connection.

6. Consider volunteering: Helping others who are going through similar challenges can be rewarding and fulfilling. Explore opportunities to volunteer within your community, as it often fosters connections and a sense of purpose.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and finding the right path forward may take time. It's essential to prioritize your mental health and seek the support you need.

[Question]
my bf is in a depressive episode atm i m still learning and would like to know more about depression while in an depressive episode is every day the same for you do you have good day in between coming out of depression do you feel much better from one day to the next or is it a slow process with back step too sorry for all the question just want to understand better what my bf is going through

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're taking the time to learn more about depression and want to understand what your boyfriend is going through. While I can't provide a diagnosis or replace a professional, I can offer some general information that might help.

Depression can indeed feel overwhelming and consistent day after day. However, it's important to remember that everyone's experience with depression is unique, and there can be variations in symptoms and functioning from one day to another. Some individuals may have moments of relief or improved mood, while for others, the difficulties may persist. It's also worth noting that treatment and coping strategies can play a role in managing depression.

In terms of treatment options, there are several approaches that can be helpful. Therapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), can assist in identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and developing healthier coping mechanisms. Medication, prescribed by a healthcare provider, may also be an option to address chemical imbalances contributing to depression. Additionally, lifestyle changes like regular exercise, healthy eating, and sufficient sleep can positively impact mood.

While these treatments can be effective, it's essential to note that they may not provide immediate results. The process of improvement often takes time, and it can involve ups and downs along the way. Collaborating with a mental health professional can help determine the best course of action tailored to your boyfriend's specific needs.

Remember, open communication with your boyfriend is crucial. Encourage him to seek support from those around him, whether friends, family, or even online communities where he can connect with others who have experienced similar challenges. Sharing experiences and coping strategies might provide valuable insights and encouragement.

Lastly, taking care of yourself is equally important. Supporting a loved one through a difficult time can be emotionally draining, so ensure you prioritize self-care. Engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, and consider reaching out to a support network for your own well-being.

Please keep in mind that my guidance is not a substitute for professional help, but I hope these suggestions can be helpful to you as you navigate this situation.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It's important to remember that you don't have to face these feelings alone. Reaching out for support is a courageous step, and there are people who can help you navigate through this difficult time.

Firstly, I want to assure you that your feelings are valid and understood. It can be overwhelming when depression takes hold and makes it difficult to find joy or purpose in life. The fact that you're reaching out shows strength and resilience in the face of such challenges.

Regarding your concerns about being a burden to those who care about you, it's common for individuals experiencing depression to struggle with this thought. However, it's crucial to recognize that seeking support from friends, family, or a therapist can provide much-needed relief and understanding. Opening up to them about what you're going through may help alleviate some of the burden you feel.

In terms of your wish to not care about how your actions might affect others, it's essential to acknowledge that our actions often impact those around us. While it may seem tempting to focus solely on our own well-being, consider the ripple effect that our choices have on those we love. Finding a balance between self-care and consideration for others can be challenging, but working towards finding that balance is an important goal to strive for.

Regarding your fear of dying, it's common for individuals experiencing depression to experience anxiety related to death. This fear can be overwhelming and distressing. Exploring coping strategies for managing these fears, such as grounding techniques or engaging in activities that bring you comfort, may be helpful. Additionally, discussing your fears with a trusted person in your life can provide support and reassurance.

When it comes to your thoughts about ridding yourself of the people who care, it's important to remember that these thoughts are a symptom of depression and should not be acted upon. Seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor can provide a safe space to process these feelings and develop healthier coping mechanisms. Regarding your experience on medication, it's understandable to have concerns about how it might change who you are. Keep in mind that everyone's experience with medication is unique, and finding the right medication and dosage may require some trial and error. Open communication with your healthcare provider about your concerns and experiences can help ensure that you find the most effective and tolerable treatment for you.

Lastly, regarding your thoughts about finding solace in oblivion, it's important to remember that there are alternative ways to find solace and peace without resorting to self-destructive behavior. Exploring different coping strategies, such as engaging in activities that bring you joy, practicing relaxation techniques, or seeking support from a therapist, can help you find solace in healthier and more constructive ways.

Remember, you have taken an important step by reaching out for support. i have no idea if this is anxiety but this is the reason why im asking lately i ve been extremely overthinking the most smallest thing and worrying about the most thing that i ve been overthinking about this happens throughout the day and disrupts my life it s even disrupting me whilst i m typing i worry and overthink thing that could cause health problem but the thing are sooo small i ve wasted so many food thinking this could be dangerous i know it sound stupid because i can barely even explain it it s taking a toll on me but i know that the other day when i got outside the house i wasn t thinking about it and i felt better but then when i got back to the house and started up again i just know i keep overthinking and worrying about the smallest thing health related i can t tell you the amount of time that i ve been back and forth to the doctor this year and last year worrying myself

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of distress due to overthinking and worrying about your health. It's great that you reached out for support, as this can be quite challenging to deal with on your own. While I'm not a mental health expert, there are some strategies you can try to help manage these anxious thoughts.

Firstly, it might be helpful to identify the specific triggers or situations that tend to provoke your overthinking. By recognizing these patterns, you can develop techniques to address them more effectively. For example, if you notice that certain situations or environments tend to trigger your worries, you could try to avoid or minimize your exposure to those triggers when possible.

Another approach you can consider is practicing mindfulness and grounding techniques. These techniques involve focusing your attention on the present moment and grounding yourself in reality. Engaging in activities such as deep breathing exercises, meditation, or even simply paying close attention to your senses can help redirect your thoughts away from excessive worries.

Additionally, challenging negative or irrational thoughts can be beneficial. When you catch yourself overthinking or catastrophizing, try to question the evidence supporting those thoughts. Are there alternative explanations or possibilities? Is there any objective proof that what you fear will actually happen? Challenging these thoughts can help reduce their power over you.

Incorporating regular physical exercise into your routine may also be helpful. Exercise has been shown to have positive effects on mental well-being, including reducing anxiety and improving mood. Finding an activity that you enjoy and can incorporate into your daily life, even in small ways, could potentially bring relief.

Lastly, seeking support from trusted friends or loved ones can provide comfort and reassurance. Talking about your worries with someone who understands and cares about you can help alleviate some of the burden you've been carrying.

Remember, these suggestions are not meant to replace professional guidance but rather offer some general coping strategies that may assist you in managing your overthinking and worries. If your symptoms persist or worsen, it would be advisable to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.

[Question]
my anxiety is so bad right now i have been vomiting and have bad pain in my stomach and abdomen lot of sweating and extreme issue sleeping last night i didn t fall asleep until am and woke up at am in a complete panic eating is very difficult for me right now and i have a sense of impending doom constantly is there anything any of you do that help with this how can i bring this up with my doctor without being committed or something should i get a short supply of benzos to get through this time i just need some advice thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now with your anxiety. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to help manage your symptoms.

Firstly, it might be helpful to try some relaxation techniques or mindfulness exercises to help calm your mind and body. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery can all be effective strategies. You could also consider incorporating activities like yoga or meditation into your daily routine as they have been known to assist with anxiety.

In terms of discussing your symptoms with a doctor, it's essential to find an approach that makes you feel comfortable. One option is to schedule a regular appointment with your primary care physician and explain how you've been feeling. Being open and honest about your experiences will allow them to better understand your situation and provide appropriate guidance or treatment options. Remember, doctors are there to support your well-being, so don't hesitate to share your concerns.

Regarding medication, it's best to consult with a healthcare professional who can evaluate your specific needs. They can assess whether medication may be appropriate for you at this time. Keep in mind that doctors typically prescribe short-term benzodiazepines sparingly due to their potential for dependence. However, they may offer alternative options such as non-benzodiazepine anxiolytics or antidepressants that can also help alleviate anxiety symptoms. It's crucial to work collaboratively with your doctor to determine the most suitable treatment plan for your situation.

Remember, seeking support from friends and loved ones can also be beneficial. Sharing your feelings and experiences with trusted individuals can provide emotional comfort and understanding. Additionally, consider exploring self-help resources such as books, podcasts, or online forums that offer coping strategies for anxiety.

Lastly, taking care of yourself physically is important too. Engaging in regular exercise, maintaining a balanced diet, and ensuring adequate sleep can all contribute to overall well-being and help manage anxiety symptoms.

Please keep in mind that these suggestions are general and may not address your specific needs. It's always a good idea to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your situation.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i am male and getting my dream education right now and will be working with young people that can t live with their parent for a multitude of reason anymore in year after year of being aimless i found that to be my dream job i am together with a nice girl and we have great chemistry i am living in my own flat and my grade and praxis are is going great i got professional help after a major mental breakdown i had year ago that made me live like a plant and got over severe depression and constant panic attack panic attack are rare and i know my trigger and how to deal with them i am confident in myself and got to reflect on my messed up childhood and problematic personality trait a couple of week ago i started feeling really anxious tho by far more than usual i am afraid of dying for stupid bodily reason and i am always so tense and have ache in my stomach and neck and my heart beat really fast from time to time and i am afraid my girlfriend will leave me that s what i am most anxious about she is really good for me and she told me that i am good for her but lately she act distant while still showing me affection in way because she isn t doing that good aswell there are reason for her to feel bad besides me but i am afraid that i might be a big reason because she wa confronted with a lot of my anxiety related issue logically i would say she won t leave me because gave me thoughtful present and still care for me by reminding me to eat and she sometimes say she miss me but she behaves so distant and it s triggering me so hard because of a toxic relationship i wa in i decided not to talk about my anxiety anymore because i don t want to lay that upon her and i told her about my abandonment issue once and will leave it at that because i don t want her to feel bad everytime she behaves distant because of her own issue that would be selfish hell she even told me she won t stop loving me even if she cant express it but my anxiety is still there the worst thing is that she doesn t want to speak about what s bothering her because she doesn t want to think about it which make me feel like it s me and then i feel like an asshole because i am not the center of the world so yeah long story short my abandonment issue are the worst thing right now i decided not to bother her with it because it s not fair but i don t know how to deal with it oh and those issue wouldn t be so bad if i weren t so anxious in general the general anxiety came with the practical part of my education but i don t know why because i am doing good i will be done with that in week and that s when i will meet her again and i hope that everything will be okay by then but i am afraid that i will be sabotaging myself before then by ruining my relationship just so that the anxiety go away

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you have a lot on your plate right now, and I can understand how overwhelming it must feel. It's great that you're pursuing your dream education and working with young people who need support. That's a wonderful thing to be doing.

Regarding your anxiety, it's completely normal to feel anxious at times, especially when there are multiple stressors in your life. It's important to remember that anxiety can be managed and worked through. Here are a few suggestions that might help:

1. Take care of yourself: Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating well, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Taking care of your physical health can have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

2. Communication with your girlfriend: While it's understandable that you don't want to burden her, having an open and honest conversation about what you both are going through could be beneficial. Sharing your feelings and concerns may help alleviate some of the anxiety you're experiencing.

3. Self-reflection: Continue reflecting on your childhood and personality traits. Understanding where your anxiety may stem from can provide valuable insights into how to address it. Consider keeping a journal to jot down your thoughts and emotions as you navigate through these reflections.

4. Seek support: Although you mentioned not wanting to burden others, it's important to remember that having a support system is crucial. Reach out to friends, family, or even online communities where you can connect with others who may be experiencing similar challenges. Sharing your experiences and receiving support can be comforting.

5. Practice relaxation techniques: Engage in activities that promote relaxation and calmness, such as deep breathing exercises, meditation, or yoga. These techniques can help reduce anxiety and promote a sense of peace.

6. Challenge negative thoughts: Anxiety often stems from negative thinking patterns. Try to identify any unhelpful thoughts that contribute to your anxiety and challenge them. Replace them with more realistic and positive thoughts.

7. Focus on the present moment: Instead of worrying about potential future problems, try to focus on the present moment. Mindfulness exercises can help you stay grounded and reduce anxiety about things that haven't happened yet.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and practice. It's important to be patient with yourself as you work through these strategies. If you find that your anxiety is significantly impacting your daily life or relationships, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized guidance and support.

Take care of yourself and remember that you're not alone in this journey.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i ve been dealing with serious depression for the last 0 year one huge thing is the mental fatigue i m always feeling in my head making it hard to get up and do thing what have you done to help relieve that so thing are much easier to do and enjoy i m planning on switching job but the mental exhaustion is making so hard to go for it so any advice would be amazing

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out for support and taking steps to address your depression. Dealing with serious depression can indeed be challenging, but there are strategies that may help alleviate the mental fatigue you're experiencing.

One approach you might find helpful is to incorporate regular physical exercise into your routine. Engaging in activities like walking, jogging, or yoga can boost your mood and reduce mental exhaustion by releasing endorphins, which are natural antidepressants. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise most days of the week.

Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness meditation can assist in calming your mind and reducing mental fatigue. These techniques can help you stay present in the moment and reduce stress. You may want to consider setting aside a few minutes each day to engage in these practices.

Another strategy to consider is establishing a consistent sleep schedule. Adequate rest is crucial for both your physical and mental well-being. Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time every day, even on weekends, to regulate your body's internal clock. Creating a relaxing bedtime routine, such as reading a book or taking a warm bath, can also promote better sleep.

When it comes to job-related concerns, it can be beneficial to explore your options and gain a clearer understanding of what you truly enjoy and find fulfilling. Consider reflecting on your interests, values, and strengths when considering a new job. It may also be worthwhile to seek out opportunities for professional development or to learn new skills that align with your passions.

Lastly, don't hesitate to reach out to friends, family, or support groups who can provide emotional support during this difficult time. Sharing your experiences and feelings with trusted individuals can offer comfort and understanding.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so it may take time to find the strategies that work best for you. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. If you ever feel overwhelmed or need additional support, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and assistance.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now, and I can understand how painful it must be to feel disconnected from your ex-boyfriend after having invested so much into the relationship. It's important to remember that relationships require effort from both sides, and sometimes people go through their own personal struggles that may affect their ability to connect with others.

Firstly, it's great that you've reached out and expressed your feelings. This is an important step in processing your emotions and finding ways to move forward. While I'm not a professional therapist, I can offer some guidance and suggestions based on my understanding of your situation.

1. Allow yourself to grieve: Losing a close friend can be incredibly challenging, and it's understandable that your grief may be impacting your emotional well-being. Take the time to mourn the loss of your friend and give yourself permission to feel the associated emotions. Consider joining a support group or seeking therapy to help you navigate this grieving process.

2. Focus on self-care: It's essential to prioritize your own well-being during this difficult time. Engage in activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of fulfillment. Explore new hobbies or revisit old ones that you used to enjoy before your relationship. Surround yourself with supportive friends or family members who can offer a listening ear and companionship.

3. Challenge negative thoughts: Overthinking is a common response when we face rejection or feel undervalued. When negative thoughts arise, try to challenge them by asking yourself if there is evidence to support these beliefs. Often, our insecurities are not based on reality but rather on our own perceptions. Practice self-compassion and remind yourself of your worth and value as an individual.

4. Seek support from loved ones: Talking to trusted friends or family members about your feelings can be incredibly helpful. They may provide a different perspective or offer advice based on their own experiences. Opening up to someone who can empathize with your situation can provide comfort and validation.

5. Consider journaling: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can be a therapeutic outlet. It allows you to process your emotions and gain clarity. Try dedicating a few minutes each day to journaling about your experiences, thoughts, and emotions. This can help you gain insights into your feelings and potentially identify patterns or triggers.

6. Explore personal growth opportunities: Use this time as an opportunity for self-reflection and personal growth. Consider taking up a new hobby or enrolling in a class that interests you. Engaging in activities that challenge you and push you out of your comfort zone can be empowering and fulfilling.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. If you find that your emotional distress persists or worsens, consider seeking professional help from a therapist who can provide you with the necessary support and guidance tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

idk if anyone else get this i get anxiety poop sometimes but i also get anxiety vomit idk if it from excessive hyperventilating when i have an attack or just from the anxiety i get super nauseous and have no choice but to go vomit this can happen every night if it particularly bad doe anyone else get this i tried looking it up and i couldn t find much regarding vomiting when having a panic anxiety attack it the worst

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really challenging to experience anxiety symptoms like vomiting during panic attacks. While I'm not a professional, there are some strategies that you might find helpful in managing these episodes.

Firstly, it could be beneficial to practice deep breathing exercises when you feel an anxiety attack coming on. Taking slow, deep breaths can help regulate your body's response and reduce the intensity of the attack. You could try inhaling deeply through your nose for a count of four, holding your breath for a count of four, and exhaling slowly through your mouth for a count of four. Repeat this pattern several times until you start to feel more calm.

Additionally, it may be helpful to identify any triggers or patterns that seem to precede your vomiting episodes. Keeping a journal to track your thoughts, feelings, and physical sensations before the episodes occur can provide valuable insights. By recognizing these triggers, you can work on finding ways to manage or avoid them.

Engaging in regular physical activity or exercise can also be beneficial for managing anxiety symptoms. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters and stress relievers. Finding an activity that you enjoy, such as walking, yoga, or dancing, can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts and promote overall well-being.

Incorporating relaxation techniques into your daily routine can also be useful. This might include practicing mindfulness or meditation exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as listening to music, reading, or taking a warm bath.

Lastly, seeking support from loved ones can make a significant difference. Sharing your experiences with trusted friends or family members can provide emotional support and understanding. They may even have suggestions or coping mechanisms that have worked for them.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it's important to find what works best for you. If these suggestions don't alleviate your symptoms or if they worsen, it would be advisable to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through an incredibly difficult time right now, and I'm here to offer you support and guidance. It's important to remember that there is hope and help available to you.

Firstly, I want to assure you that you are not alone in feeling this way. Many people have experienced similar thoughts and emotions, and it's crucial to reach out for assistance during these challenging times. Remember that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness.

One step you can take is to establish a support system around you. Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support and understanding. Sharing your feelings with someone who cares about you can make a significant difference in how you feel.

Additionally, consider exploring different coping mechanisms that may help you manage your pain and emotions. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of calmness can be beneficial. This could include hobbies, creative outlets, listening to music, or spending time in nature if possible.

Another suggestion is to seek professional help. There are mental health professionals who specialize in crisis intervention and can provide immediate assistance. They can work with you to develop coping strategies and explore treatment options tailored to your specific needs.

In addition to these steps, it's important to prioritize self-care. Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial during this time. Ensure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular exercise. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness can help alleviate some of the distress you're experiencing.

Lastly, if you ever find yourself in immediate danger or feel unable to keep yourself safe, please reach out to emergency services or contact a helpline specifically created for crisis support. They will be able to provide you with the necessary assistance and connect you with appropriate resources.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to ask for help. You deserve support and compassion as you navigate through this difficult period. Keep reaching out and stay connected with those who care about you.

[Question]
i have irrational fear of a home invasion being attacked by a stranger for context even thing like elderly woman with cane walking behind me sends me into panic mode me and my fianc just bought our first home together after renting for year instead of me being able to rest after a long day of moving i am instead laying awake because the house is settling every 0 second and i keep thinking it s an intruder coming to kill me this ha been going on for two hour my heart keep pounding out of my chest randomly and i keep getting so frozen with fear that i hold my breath my mind is working overtime playing escape plan confrontation scenario on repeat so i can t relax this is so fucking irrational i hate it i ve been this way a long a i can remember but ugh i know why house creek i also know this home is older which is something i love about it during the day but i can not seem to think logically about this every pop creek and bang is sending me into panic mode and i don t have any remedy i m sick of being constantly on alert for no reason this is an extremely safe neighborhood and i should not need to be this worried over nothing some night are better than others but why do i even have to go through this at all i apologize for the rant but i am so exhausted and i just want to sleep but i keep getting snapped awake

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of distress due to your fear of home invasion and the anxiety it brings. It's understandable that these thoughts are causing you to feel on edge, especially in your new home. Here are some suggestions that may help you manage your fear:

1. Deep Breathing: When you notice yourself holding your breath or feeling overwhelmed, take slow deep breaths. Inhale deeply through your nose, hold for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help calm your body and mind.

2. Grounding Techniques: Engage your senses to bring yourself back to the present moment. Focus on things around you, such as the texture of an object, the sound of your surroundings, or the sensation of your feet touching the ground. This can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts.

3. Progressive Muscle Relaxation: Tense and relax each muscle group in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. This technique can help release tension and promote relaxation.

4. Challenge Negative Thoughts: Recognize that your fear may be irrational, but it's important to acknowledge and address the underlying anxiety. Write down your fears and challenge them by asking yourself if there is evidence to support them. Remind yourself that the house is safe, and you are in control.

5. Create a Routine: Establish a bedtime routine that promotes relaxation and good sleep hygiene. Take a warm shower, avoid stimulating activities before bed, and create a calm and comfortable sleep environment. Consider using earplugs or a white noise machine to block out distracting sounds.

6. Seek Support: Talk to someone you trust about your fears and anxieties. Sharing your feelings can provide relief and perspective. Additionally, consider joining a support group or seeking therapy to work through your fears in a structured and supportive setting.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and practice. Be patient with yourself as you work towards finding strategies that work best for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hello i ve not posted here before but i ve wanted to for a while always debating back and forth whether or not to do this but here it go i think i have some general anxiety i cope decently well with it physical exercise like running ha really helped my main problem is driving i know how to drive i have my license but i never do i m terrified of it i m turning i ve maybe driven thirty time in my entire 0 year of owning a license i don t know what it is the idea of crashing the traffic i ve gotten away with it so far living in nyc but it s something i want to do more of i just never seem to be able to do so doe anyone have any tip any advice they could recommend thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you reached out and shared your experience with general anxiety, specifically regarding your fear of driving. I can understand how challenging it must be for you to navigate this fear and desire to do something that feels intimidating.

To address your concerns, there are a few strategies you can try to help overcome your fear of driving. Firstly, it might be helpful to gradually expose yourself to driving situations in a controlled and safe manner. You could start by practicing in low-stress environments such as empty parking lots or quiet residential areas where you feel more comfortable. As you gain confidence, you can gradually increase the difficulty level by driving in busier areas or during different times of the day.

Another technique that may assist you is deep breathing exercises. When you notice anxiety or fear arising, take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help calm your nervous system and reduce the intensity of your anxiety symptoms.

Additionally, it may be beneficial to challenge any negative thoughts or beliefs you have about driving. Often, our fears are fueled by irrational or exaggerated thoughts. Take some time to identify any unhelpful thoughts you may have related to driving and try to replace them with more realistic and balanced ones. For example, instead of thinking "I will definitely crash," consider the evidence that supports a positive outcome, such as "Millions of people drive safely every day."

Seeking support from loved ones can also make a difference. Consider sharing your concerns with someone you trust, such as a friend or family member, who can provide encouragement and accompany you on driving practice sessions. Having someone supportive by your side can help alleviate anxiety and provide reassurance.

Lastly, if you find that your fear continues to significantly impact your daily life or becomes overwhelming, it may be worth considering seeking professional help. A mental health therapist or counselor can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can assist you in developing coping strategies, addressing underlying issues, and working towards overcoming your fear.

Remember, progress takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories. You have already taken an important step by reaching out for advice, and I believe that with determination and support, you can overcome your fear of driving and engage in the activities you desire.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have suffered with shortness of breath due to anxiety ever since i wa diagnosed with gad generalized anxiety disorder about year ago doe anyone else have this it just feel like i will stop breathing doe anyone have any coping mechanism around this a it s really horrible a well a shortness of breath i also feel shaky and tingly and i have no idea how to calm down when i have these episode

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly challenging to experience shortness of breath due to anxiety, especially when it has become a regular occurrence for you. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this struggle, as many individuals with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) often report experiencing similar symptoms.

To address your first question, finding relief from shortness of breath during anxiety episodes is possible. One technique you might find helpful is deep breathing exercises. When you feel the onset of anxiety, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and exhaling slowly through your mouth. This can help regulate your breathing and bring a sense of calmness.

Additionally, engaging in regular physical exercise can be beneficial for managing anxiety symptoms. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters and can help reduce feelings of anxiety. Finding activities that you enjoy, such as walking, yoga, or dancing, can provide an outlet for releasing tension and promoting relaxation.

Another coping mechanism you may consider exploring is mindfulness or meditation. These practices involve focusing your attention on the present moment without judgment. By grounding yourself in the here and now, you can redirect your focus away from anxious thoughts and sensations. There are various resources available, including apps and online videos, that can guide you through mindfulness exercises.

In addition to these techniques, it may be helpful to identify any triggers or patterns that precede your anxiety episodes. Keeping a journal to record your thoughts, feelings, and experiences surrounding these episodes can assist you in recognizing patterns and potential stressors. Once identified, you can work on developing strategies to manage or minimize those triggers.

Lastly, seeking support from loved ones can make a significant difference. Sharing your experiences with trusted friends or family members can provide emotional support and understanding. They may also offer insights or suggestions based on their own experiences.

Remember, everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, so it may take time to find the coping mechanisms that work best for you. It can be beneficial to experiment with different techniques and approaches to discover what resonates with you personally.

Please keep in mind that while these suggestions can be helpful, it's important to consult with a healthcare professional for a comprehensive evaluation and guidance tailored to your specific needs. They can provide personalized support and potentially explore additional treatment options, such as therapy or medication, if necessary.

Take care of yourself and remember that there is hope for managing and overcoming anxiety.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

like the title say i m doing bad at work i work a a claim adjuster for a big insurance company and i m really bad at it the job requires a tremendous amount of organization and i just simply do not have those skill it s my first big job out of college and i m failing it embarrassing and it s crushing my confidence i constantly worry about my job security being this anxious all the time is making me run out of steam quickly i find it hard to even force myself to look for another job bc of the little free time i get and how tired i am at the end of the day i feel like a burden to my parent and girlfriend because i constantly vent break down to them i did start seeing a therapist recently and he s helped but it feel like it build up a lot until i get to talk it out with him what trigged me to write this today is i made another fuck up at work and had to tell my bos she s extremely nice but had to be honest with me that my performance could result in corrective action i know that doesn t mean termination exactly but that is definitely on the table i have so many case and i just know there s at least a couple more fuck ups in there that i haven t found yet i feel like it s inevitable that i get let go and i m just not prepared to deal with the embarrassment of it it s eating at me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and struggling with your performance at work. It's understandable that you're feeling anxious and concerned about your job security. Let's break down your concerns and see if we can find some solutions together.

First, it's important to acknowledge that feeling inadequate or struggling with job performance is a common experience, especially when starting a new job. It takes time to adjust and learn the ropes. Remember to be patient with yourself as you navigate through this process.

Given that organization is a crucial aspect of your job, it may be helpful to develop and improve those skills. One way to do this is by creating a system or routine that helps you stay organized. You could try using tools like calendars, to-do lists, or folders to keep track of your cases and deadlines. Additionally, consider seeking out online resources or workshops that provide tips and techniques for enhancing organizational skills.

Since you mentioned that you often feel overwhelmed and tired at the end of the day, it's essential to prioritize self-care. Make sure you're getting enough restful sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that recharge you mentally and physically. Taking short breaks throughout the day and practicing stress-management techniques, such as deep breathing or mindfulness exercises, can also help maintain your energy levels.

Regarding your feelings of being a burden to your parents and girlfriend, it's natural to seek support from loved ones during challenging times. However, it's also important to find a balance. Consider discussing your concerns with them less frequently or finding alternative ways to cope, such as journaling or engaging in hobbies that bring you joy and relaxation.

Lastly, while therapy can be beneficial, it's also important to take actionable steps towards resolving your challenges. In addition to seeking professional guidance, take proactive measures to address your struggles at work. For example, schedule regular check-ins with your supervisor to discuss your performance and address any concerns openly. Showing your commitment to improvement will demonstrate your engagement and dedication to the job.

Remember, change takes time and effort. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and focus on small steps forward. You have the ability to adapt, grow, and overcome these challenges. Keep an open line of communication with your supervisor, continue seeking support from your therapist, and explore strategies to enhance your organizational skills and self-care routine.

Take things one day at a time, and remember that setbacks are a part of life. With determination and perseverance, you can improve your performance at work and regain your confidence.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you reached out and shared your experiences with us. It can be really tough to navigate social situations, especially when you have anxiety and other disorders like MDD, ODD, ADHD, and polysubstance addiction. It's understandable that you may feel frustrated and isolated due to these challenges.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that having social anxiety is not a choice. It's a real struggle that many people face, and it's not your fault. Remember that you are not alone in this journey, and there are others who understand what you're going through.

Building social skills can take time and practice, but it is definitely possible. One step you can take is to gradually expose yourself to social situations that make you uncomfortable. Start small by engaging in activities or hobbies that align with your interests. This can help you meet people who share similar interests and make connections in a more natural and relaxed way.

Additionally, consider seeking support from a therapist or counselor who specializes in anxiety. They can provide guidance and strategies tailored to your specific needs. Therapy can offer a safe space for you to explore your feelings, work on building self-esteem, and develop effective coping mechanisms.

Another suggestion is to join support groups or communities where you can connect with others who have similar experiences. Sharing your thoughts and feelings with people who truly understand can provide validation and a sense of belonging. Online platforms and forums can also be helpful resources to find individuals who share your interests and are open to making new connections.

Lastly, it's important to address the substance abuse you mentioned. While using substances may temporarily alleviate some of the pain and discomfort, it can also lead to negative consequences and exacerbate your struggles. Consider reaching out to a support group or a counselor who specializes in addiction. They can provide you with healthier coping mechanisms and strategies to overcome substance abuse.

Remember, building social skills and finding a sense of belonging takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories. You deserve to have meaningful connections and friendships in your life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i saw a new pcp for an annual physical and while i wa there figured i d mention some of the physical symptom of anxiety i wa having to make sure it wa not actually medical i told her it often feel like my throat is really tight and on the verge of closing her only reply a she roll her eye that is literally impossible if your throat wa closing you wouldn t be talking to me right now me no duh obviously not but it feel like it s closing she wa the worst doctor i ve ever seen which is saying a lot and i wa so mad walking out of that appointment for other reason a well but the day after a my throat wa tightening i just remembered her saying it s literally impossible and couldn t stop laughing

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you had a frustrating experience with your new PCP when you mentioned the physical symptoms of anxiety you've been experiencing. It's understandable that her dismissive response left you feeling unheard and upset.

Firstly, it's important to remember that finding a good doctor-patient relationship is crucial for effective healthcare. A doctor who rolls their eyes and dismisses your concerns can be disheartening and unhelpful. It's unfortunate that she didn't take the time to understand your symptoms or offer any support.

Regarding your throat symptoms, it's common for people with anxiety to experience physical sensations such as tightness or a feeling of closure. While it may seem counterintuitive, these sensations are often a result of the body's stress response rather than an actual medical issue. The good news is that there are strategies you can try to manage these symptoms.

One technique that might help is deep breathing exercises. When you notice your throat tightening, take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focusing on your breath can help calm your nervous system and reduce the intensity of the physical sensations.

Another approach you could consider is progressive muscle relaxation. This involves tensing and then releasing each muscle group in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. By consciously relaxing your muscles, you may find relief from the tension in your throat.

In addition to these techniques, it can be helpful to explore any underlying causes or triggers for your anxiety. Journaling your thoughts and feelings can provide insight into patterns or situations that contribute to your symptoms. Identifying these triggers can empower you to make positive changes in your life to minimize their impact.

Remember, managing anxiety is a journey, and finding the right coping mechanisms may take time. It's essential to be patient with yourself and seek support from trusted friends, loved ones, or even online communities who can provide understanding and encouragement.

Lastly, if you feel comfortable, it may be worth considering finding a new PCP who can offer a more empathetic and supportive approach to your healthcare. Finding a doctor who listens and understands your concerns can greatly improve your overall well-being.

Take care of yourself and remember that you have the power to take steps towards managing your anxiety and finding the support you deserve.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i ve noticed that for a few glorious minute in the morning right after waking up i m great calm unbothered soft but then i can feel stress in my body and then i m not sure how to get rid of it and it build a anxiety doe how do you all get rid of body stress in the early morning

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be challenging to deal with body stress and anxiety in the mornings, but there are some strategies that may help you manage it. Here are a few suggestions:

1. Deep Breathing: Start your day by practicing deep breathing exercises. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce stress.

2. Stretching: Incorporate stretching into your morning routine. Gentle stretches can help release tension in your muscles and promote a sense of calmness. You can try yoga or Tai Chi exercises, which are known for their stress-reducing effects.

3. Mindfulness or Meditation: Engaging in mindfulness or meditation practices can be beneficial for managing stress and anxiety. Spend a few minutes each morning focusing on the present moment, observing your thoughts and sensations without judgment. There are also many guided meditation apps available that can assist you in this practice.

4. Physical Activity: Regular exercise has been shown to reduce stress and improve mood. Consider incorporating physical activity into your daily routine, even if it's just a short walk or stretching session. Exercise releases endorphins, which can help boost your mood and alleviate stress.

5. Prioritize Self-Care: Make sure to prioritize self-care activities throughout your day. This could include engaging in hobbies you enjoy, taking breaks when needed, getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and maintaining a healthy work-life balance. Taking care of yourself holistically can contribute to overall well-being and stress reduction.

6. Seek Support: If your body stress and anxiety persist despite trying these techniques, consider reaching out to a mental health professional or counselor who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can help you explore the underlying causes of your stress and develop coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, finding what works best for you may involve some trial and error. It's important to be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can imagine how challenging it must be for you to adjust to this new situation while also managing your mental health conditions. It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure about how to improve your job performance. I want to offer some suggestions that might help.

First, it's important to address the issue of feeling like you're constantly making mistakes at work. One possible explanation could be the stress and anxiety caused by your mental health conditions. When we're under a lot of pressure, it can be difficult to focus and perform at our best. It may be worth discussing with your therapist or counselor if there are any adjustments that can be made to your treatment plan to better manage your symptoms.

Additionally, finding a balance between being thorough and covering the basics can be tricky. One approach you could try is setting realistic goals for yourself. Break down your tasks into smaller, manageable steps and prioritize them based on importance and urgency. This way, you can ensure that you cover the essentials while still paying attention to detail.

Communication with your supervisor may also be key. Since you mentioned that you were told to ask questions if you don't understand, it might be helpful to take them up on their offer. Ask for clarification when needed and seek feedback on your work. i m not sure if this is the right subreddit to go to but i don t know where else to go my spouse ha struggled with severe depression his whole life it is genetic his dad wa the same any amount of pressure make him worse he constantly feel a though life is not worth living and he s a lost cause he will never feel okay and just want the pain to go away we have a baby coming any day now and i wa worried that pressure wa gon na send him over the edge we have been talking about having him voluntarily go to a psych ward and see if they can help kinda a a last ditch effort before i just give him permission to end it today he talked to his counselor about going to one in a few week after the baby wa here and they came and picked him up an hour later he is pissed doesn t want to be there which i understand is normal he feel completely betrayed by his councellor and never want to go back i m worried that now he is going to pretend like he is fine just to get out the point of this is to get help why won t he just take it i m scared the mental hospital won t help at all i just need you guy who have been there before to be honest with me did it help what thing helped and what made it worse if it doe help or when he come back home what are some thing i can do to continue the healing process or just make his life easier anything else you feel to share please do i hate not knowing thing and this is really killing me right now

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really glad that you reached out and shared your concerns about your spouse's struggle with severe depression. It takes a lot of courage to seek support, and I appreciate your efforts in wanting to help him through this difficult time.

While I can't offer professional advice or specific treatment recommendations, I can share some general suggestions that may be helpful for both you and your spouse during this challenging period. Remember, these are just general ideas and may not work perfectly for your unique situation:

1. Open communication: Continue having open and honest conversations with your spouse. Encourage him to express his feelings and thoughts without judgment. Active listening and empathy can go a long way in fostering understanding and emotional support between the two of you.

2. Seek professional help together: Consider finding a therapist or counselor who specializes in couples therapy or trauma. They can provide guidance on how to navigate these difficult times as a couple and help both of you heal together. Additionally, they can assist in addressing any unresolved trauma that may be contributing to your spouse's struggles.

3. Explore different coping strategies: Encourage your spouse to explore various coping mechanisms that work for him. This might include engaging in activities he enjoys, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or meditation, journaling, or seeking support from trusted friends or family members.

4. Create a supportive environment: Make sure your home is a safe and supportive space for your spouse. This means providing emotional support, understanding, and encouragement to take small steps towards healing. Offer to help with practical tasks and responsibilities to alleviate some of the pressure he may be feeling.

5. Self-care: Don't forget to take care of yourself too. Being a caregiver can be emotionally and physically draining, so it's important to prioritize your own well-being. Seek support from friends, engage in activities that bring you joy, and consider joining a support group for caregivers who have experienced similar challenges.

6. Educate yourself: Learn more about depression and its effects on individuals and relationships. Understanding the nature of depression can help both of you make informed decisions and find appropriate resources. However, keep in mind that everyone's experiences are unique, so it's essential to tailor any information or strategies you learn to fit your specific situation.

Remember, these suggestions are not a substitute for professional help, but they may provide some guidance and support during this difficult time. It's important to remember that healing takes time and that progress can be up and down. Be patient with yourself and your spouse as you navigate this journey together.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m currently taking 0mg effexor xr for anxiety and depression i ve also taken lexapro 0mg for year and zoloft 00mg for a year both had similar effect barely put a dent in my anxiety and really helped with the severe symptom of depression but it s still there my anxiety is still bad particularly my physical symptom i always feel on edge and nervous i can always feel my heart pounding hard not fast regardless of my mental state and it s the most debilitating symptom i feel i can never relax and never truly enjoy myself because of how anxious i feel i take propranolol 0mg twice a day and is the only thing that help a little with the physical symptom but they re still problematic i have tried meditation breathing exercise exercise i have read a multitude of book on cognitive behavioral therapy acceptance and commitment therapy and mindfulness no exercise in the book ha helped with the symptom whatsoever i should also mention i have had test for my thyroid adrenal any gi or diet issue antibody etc and i m sure i can rule out physical cause is anyone else in a similar boat to me and found buspirone helped if no ha anything helped you thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with significant anxiety and depression for quite some time, and it's understandable that you're seeking relief from your symptoms. It can be frustrating when medications that have worked for others don't seem to have the same effect on you.

While I'm not a mental health expert, there are a few strategies you could consider exploring to help manage your anxiety. One approach you might find helpful is to focus on grounding techniques. These techniques involve bringing your attention back to the present moment and engaging your senses. For example, you could try focusing on the sensation of your feet on the ground or the sounds around you. This may help distract from anxious thoughts and bring a sense of calm.

Another strategy you could try is deep breathing exercises. When we're anxious, our breath tends to become shallow and rapid. Taking slow, deep breaths can activate the body's relaxation response and help reduce anxiety. You can practice this by inhaling deeply through your nose, holding your breath for a few seconds, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth. Repeat this several times until you start to feel more relaxed.

Additionally, it might be worth exploring other treatment options beyond medication. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a widely recognized and effective approach for managing anxiety. CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns that contribute to anxiety. It also involves developing coping skills and implementing behavioral changes to reduce anxiety. While you mentioned you've tried reading books on CBT, it might be beneficial to work with a trained therapist who can provide personalized guidance and support.

In addition to therapy, incorporating lifestyle changes into your routine can also be helpful. Regular exercise, such as walking or yoga, can release endorphins and improve your mood. Prioritizing healthy sleep habits, including getting enough restful sleep each night, can also positively impact your mental well-being. Additionally, consider exploring stress-reducing activities that you enjoy, such as hobbies or spending time in nature.

Lastly, connecting with others who understand what you're going through can be incredibly valuable. Consider joining support groups or seeking out online communities where you can share experiences and learn from others who may be facing similar challenges. Sometimes hearing about other people's journeys can provide new insights and potential solutions.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find the strategies that work best for you. It's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process and celebrate small victories along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

so i started having suicidal thought in april of last year and they lasted until around november in october i started hanging out with a girl and we started becoming good friend not romantic just friendship my mental health started getting a lot better after a couple month of friendship with her and it s kept getting better ever since a few day ago i made a passive aggressive comment that really upset her she won t text me back now i ve tried apologizing and trying to make thing right with her but i haven t heard back from her i m afraid i ve ruined this friendship forever and now my suicidal thought are back for the first time since last year i always hurt the people that i care about and i hate myself so much that i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot, and I'm here to offer some guidance and support. It's important to remember that I'm not a professional, but I can provide some suggestions based on my understanding.

Firstly, it's great that you reached out and shared your experiences with trusted friends or family members who could support you during difficult times. It takes courage to open up about personal struggles, and it's important to have a support system in place.

Regarding your suicidal thoughts, it's crucial to prioritize your mental health. If you're feeling overwhelmed and having persistent suicidal thoughts, it may be helpful to seek professional help from a therapist or counselor who can provide specialized guidance and support tailored to your needs. They can assist you in developing coping strategies and exploring the underlying factors contributing to your thoughts.

In terms of your friendship, it's understandable that you're worried about how your comment may have affected your friend. Communication is key in any relationship, and it can be helpful to express your feelings and concerns directly, but respectfully, to your friend. Apologize sincerely for any harm caused and listen to their perspective without judgment. Give them the space they need and allow time for the situation to diffuse. Remember, friendships can go through challenges, and with effort and understanding, they often recover.

Additionally, consider reflecting on your behavior and emotions during moments of distress. Passive-aggressive comments can be hurtful, and it might be beneficial to explore healthier ways to express your emotions when you're feeling overwhelmed. This could involve journaling, engaging in creative outlets, or talking to someone you trust.

Lastly, practicing self-care is essential. Engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or connecting with loved ones. Taking care of your physical and emotional well-being can help build resilience and provide a solid foundation for healthier relationships.

Remember, these are just suggestions and what matters most is seeking personalized guidance from a mental health professional who can provide you with the appropriate support and tools.
