so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've had this epiphany about your stutter and how it doesn't have to define who you are as a person. It can be challenging to change how we perceive ourselves, but with time and practice, it is definitely possible to become more confident with your stutter.

One suggestion I have is to start by working on managing your anxiety. Anxiety often fuels stuttering, so finding ways to reduce anxiety can help improve your speech. One technique you might find helpful is deep breathing exercises. Taking slow, deep breaths can help calm your mind and body, making it easier to speak confidently. You could try incorporating these exercises into your daily routine or practicing them before situations where you might feel anxious.

Another strategy that may assist you in owning your stutter is reframing your thoughts. Negative thoughts about your stutter can perpetuate feelings of insecurity and self-doubt. Challenge those negative thoughts by replacing them with positive and empowering ones. Remind yourself that your stutter doesn't diminish your worth or character as a person. Focus on your strengths and what makes you unique and valuable.

Practicing self-acceptance is also crucial. Embrace your stutter rather than trying to hide or suppress it. Stuttering is a part of who you are, and accepting it can set you free from unnecessary stress and shame. Try to cultivate a mindset of self-compassion and understanding. Treat yourself with kindness and compassion, just as you would treat a close friend who stutters.

Engaging in activities that boost your confidence can also be beneficial. Find hobbies or interests that allow you to express yourself freely and build your self-esteem. Engaging in activities that you enjoy and excel at can help shift the focus away from your stutter and enhance your overall sense of self-worth.

Lastly, seeking support from others who stutter or joining a support group can provide you with a sense of belonging and understanding. Connecting with individuals who have similar experiences can offer valuable insights and encouragement. Sharing your challenges and progress with others who can relate may help you feel less alone on this journey.

Remember, building confidence takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself throughout this process. Celebrate small victories and acknowledge the progress you make along the way. With persistence and self-belief, you can develop the confidence to embrace your stutter and project a more charismatic and confident image.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

for context i m an english teacher at a small private english school the school is so small i m the only teacher no sub i got my period last night and a always the first day is the worst cramp headache nausea needing the loo every minute and i feel so freaking cold today no matter what i do i just can t seem to get warm so i cancelled my two afternoon lesson and asked the receptionist to deal with a meeting with a potential client herself i mean that s pretty much her job anyway but i feel so guilty for cancelling the class the nausea got worse a soon a i sent the text to my bos i feel bad that i have to cancel two class in one day especially since i had a week holiday the week before last maybe the student are losing too much lesson time this year my class today were from to 0 and then to but i don t go home in the gap between meaning i d have to sit at my desk with nothing comfy or warm for hour all while feeling really crappy idk just looking for someone to tell me it ok to take a sick day if i need it and tell the anxiety voice to shut the heck up edit thank you so much to everyone who commented and got me through the day i went to bed feeling better emotionally and physically than when i got up today is a new day

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a tough time today, and I can understand how challenging it must be for you to teach while feeling unwell. It's important to prioritize your health and well-being, so taking a sick day when needed is definitely a good idea.

To address your concerns about canceling classes, it's understandable that you may feel guilty or worry about the impact on your students. However, remember that you are only one person, and it's not uncommon for teachers to have occasional absences due to illness or other reasons. Your students will likely understand and adapt to the situation as long as you communicate effectively with them.

Consider discussing your situation openly with your students at the beginning of the class. Let them know that you're not feeling well and that you'll do your best to provide a productive lesson despite your discomfort. You could also consider having a substitute teacher or another trusted colleague cover your classes temporarily. This way, you can focus on taking care of yourself without worrying too much about the teaching aspect.

Regarding your symptoms, it's common for women to experience cramps, headaches, and nausea during menstruation. To help alleviate these symptoms, you can try various methods such as taking painkillers, applying heat packs to your abdomen, or practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation. Additionally, staying hydrated and eating small, frequent meals can help maintain your energy levels.

To cope with feeling cold, you can try wearing layers of warm clothing, using a hot water bottle or electric blanket, or engaging in physical activities that generate heat, such as dancing or doing jumping jacks. If these strategies don't work, it might be helpful to consult a healthcare professional for further guidance.

Remember, it's essential to listen to your body and give yourself permission to rest and recover when needed. Take care of yourself and don't hesitate to seek support from friends, family, or colleagues during this time.

Understanding the root cause of your feelings can guide you towards potential solutions. You could try identifying any specific triggers or patterns that make you feel empty or disconnected during the school day.

In terms of coping strategies, finding activities outside of school that bring you joy and fulfillment can be beneficial. Additionally, spending time with supportive friends or family members who appreciate and value you can help counterbalance the negative feelings experienced at school.

Communicating your concerns to someone you trust, such as a close friend, family member, or teacher, may also be helpful. If you find it challenging to express yourself verbally, writing down your thoughts and feelings in a journal can be an effective alternative. Journaling can serve as a therapeutic tool, allowing you to process and understand your emotions more deeply.

Lastly, if these feelings persist or worsen over time, seeking professional guidance from a mental health expert could be beneficial. They can provide personalized strategies and techniques to address your specific challenges and offer additional support tailored to your needs.

[Question]
hi last year in matheletics i managed to bag at least top 0 but suddenly this year my playing condition have dropped because when i look at the leaderboard every time it make me more anxious and lead to bad performance in the competition now i can not even reach top 000 this ha been making me more stressed and now i even have mixed feeling to never take part in any of these competition even though it thing that i like are there any way to at least calm myself down

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're feeling really stressed and overwhelmed due to your performance in this year's mathematics competitions. It's understandable that looking at the leaderboard causes you anxiety and affects your performance. Here are some suggestions to help you calm yourself down and cope with the situation:

1. Take a step back: Give yourself permission to take a break from constantly checking the leaderboard. Focus on your own progress and growth instead of comparing yourself to others.

2. Set realistic goals: Instead of fixating on reaching the top 0 or 000, set more attainable goals for yourself. Break down your objectives into smaller milestones that are achievable within a reasonable timeframe.

3. Practice self-care: Engage in activities that promote relaxation and well-being. This could include hobbies you enjoy, spending time with loved ones, exercising regularly, getting enough sleep, and practicing mindfulness or meditation.

4. Seek support: Reach out to friends, family, or mentors who can provide encouragement and guidance. Talking about your feelings with someone you trust can be incredibly helpful in relieving stress and gaining perspective.

5. Challenge negative thoughts: Recognize and challenge any negative thoughts or beliefs that may be contributing to your anxiety. Replace them with positive affirmations and focus on your strengths and accomplishments.

6. Explore alternative ways to engage: If participating in competitions is causing you excessive stress, consider exploring other avenues where you can still engage with your passion for mathematics. For example, join study groups, attend workshops, or participate in problem-solving clubs.

7. Prioritize self-compassion: Be kind to yourself and acknowledge that setbacks and challenges are a normal part of growth. Treat yourself with compassion and understand that mistakes and lower performance are not personal failures.

Remember, finding what you enjoy and pursuing it should bring you joy and fulfillment. If the pressure and anxiety become too overwhelming, it might be beneficial to reassess your priorities and find a balance that allows you to enjoy your passion without excessive stress.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i ve struggled w executive dysfunction for 9 year throughout my year of college there wa not one assignment that i did not do the night before it wa due i studied late ate terribly amp went thru a terrible depression a year after graduating i still have a really hard time doing thing in general i stall before i do anything at all amp it oftentimes lead to me not doing the thing at all also i kind of live my entire life on pause only taking care of myself when i have something planned or to look forward to i left my job that i wa insanely good at bc the commitment amp longevity terrified me why can t i function amp what ha helped u work thru these feeling

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with executive dysfunction for quite some time, and it's causing a lot of distress in your life. It can be really challenging to constantly put things off until the last minute and struggle with procrastination. I'm here to offer you guidance and suggestions on how to work through these feelings and improve your ability to function effectively.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that change takes time and effort. Breaking the cycle of procrastination will require some self-reflection and developing new habits. One strategy that may help is to create a structured routine for yourself. This can include setting specific goals and deadlines, breaking tasks down into smaller, manageable steps, and creating a schedule or to-do list to keep track of everything. By having a clear plan in place, it can be easier to stay focused and avoid putting things off until the last minute.

Another helpful technique is to identify and challenge any negative thoughts or beliefs that may be contributing to your lack of motivation. It's common for individuals with executive dysfunction to have self-doubt and feel overwhelmed by tasks. Try to focus on your strengths and accomplishments instead of dwelling on perceived failures. Practice self-compassion and remind yourself that everyone makes mistakes and faces challenges at times.

Additionally, finding ways to increase your overall motivation can be beneficial. Consider incorporating activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of fulfillment into your daily routine. Engaging in hobbies, spending time with loved ones, or pursuing personal interests can help you feel more engaged and motivated in your everyday life.

In terms of accountability, consider finding an accountability partner or seeking support from a trusted friend or family member. Sharing your goals and progress with someone else can provide a sense of responsibility and encouragement. Additionally, if you're comfortable, you could explore joining a support group or seeking therapy to work through these challenges with the guidance of a professional.

Remember, overcoming executive dysfunction is a process, and setbacks are normal. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. With time and consistent effort, you can develop healthier habits and improve your ability to function effectively.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
my memory s fading i m losing weight i don t sleep sex feel hollow i have no motivation to do anything and i frequently think about death i ve been seeing these symptom in myself on and off again for the past few year but never really put them together until now i attributed the weight loss to a study i read stating that just thinking about working out can have benefit despite not actually working out i never really thought of it a a symptom i just saw it a a positive slightly inexplicable development in my life i think i read that i have passive intrusive thought or something like that essentially i think about what it would be like if i wa dead but not about how i would want to die or anything like that the reason for it wa always lost on me i just learned to live with it my sleep issue motivation issue and lack of sexual pleasure have always been present so i never really thought twice about them i thought the memory loss wa due to my rare and infrequent use of recreational psychedelics when i connected all of these together i spent about 0 minute just trying to remember what i had for dinner last night which i found fairly upsetting a up until my teenage year i had an immaculate memory i d still consider myself happy at least to the extent that i ve always known but the symptom are there nevertheless and i m just finding the whole thing quite strange

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling concerned about the symptoms you've been experiencing. It's important to remember that I am not a mental health professional, but I can offer some guidance and suggestions based on your description.

Firstly, it's great that you're taking the time to reflect on your symptoms and connect the dots. This self-awareness can be an important step in understanding what may be going on. While I can't diagnose you, there are some general strategies that may help manage these symptoms.

Regarding your fading memory, it can be helpful to implement memory-boosting techniques into your daily routine. These can include creating a structured schedule, setting reminders for important tasks, and engaging in activities that stimulate your brain, such as puzzles or learning something new.

In terms of your weight loss, it's essential to prioritize self-care and ensure you're nourishing your body properly. Consider consulting with a healthcare professional or a nutritionist who can provide personalized advice based on your specific needs.

Your sleep issues can significantly impact your overall well-being. Establishing a consistent sleep routine and creating a relaxing bedtime ritual can promote better sleep. Additionally, avoiding screens before bed and creating a comfortable sleep environment can contribute to more restful nights.

Loss of motivation and interest in activities can be challenging, but finding new hobbies or revisiting old ones might help reignite your enthusiasm. Trying different activities and exploring new interests can provide a sense of purpose and fulfillment.

Regarding your thoughts about death, it's common for individuals to have such thoughts from time to time. However, if these thoughts persist or become overwhelming, it may be beneficial to discuss them with a trusted friend or loved one. Sharing your feelings can provide support and reassurance.

Lastly, while forgetting something as simple as what you had for dinner last night can be frustrating, it's important not to place too much significance on this symptom alone. Our memories can fluctuate at times, and it could be due to various factors, including stress or fatigue.

Remember, these suggestions are not a substitute for professional help, but they may provide some guidance as you navigate your symptoms. If you feel that your symptoms are significantly impacting your daily life or well-being, it's important to seek support from a mental health professional who can offer personalized advice and assistance.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m starting a new job tomorrow and i m extremely anxious about it i m excited to start this new chapter but i just wish i didn t feel so nauseous right now i ve come really far in overcoming my anxiety but i ve taken everything slowly one baby step at a time this is a huge step the only job i ve had in the past year is instacarting grocery shop amp delivery that i started month ago i did everything at my own pace day a week and maybe a few order a day this job i m starting is hour shift time a week i shouldn t have set myself up for so much but i need to start working towards my career a a dog groomer and this bathing job is an incredible opportunity to do so my living situation is changing soon in that i will need to bring money to the table so i didn t have much of a choice the worst part is i can t actually bathe any dog until i ve learned from the other groomer how to do it which will take time so i worry that the day will go by really slowly because i won t even be doing anything or getting paid until i am ready to start bathing which i don t know how long that will take a friend of mine who work there in the pet store not in the grooming room pulled a lot of string for me with the bos a well my entire family and boyfriend family know i m starting tomorrow and are so happy to see me finally starting to do something meaningful they ve all had a problem with my not working for year because of my anxiety i just feel like not only for my sake but for everyone else s sake i can not screw this up i feel like i m throwing myself into the deep end and hoping i can swim

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Starting a new job can definitely be nerve-wracking, especially when it's your first step towards your career. It's completely normal to feel anxious about it, but remember that you've come a long way in overcoming your anxiety. Take things one step at a time and focus on the positive aspects of this new opportunity.

Firstly, let's address your physical symptoms like nausea. It could be due to the anxiety you're experiencing. One technique you can try is deep breathing exercises. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help calm your body and mind.

Regarding your career change, it's great that you're pursuing your passion as a dog groomer. Remember that every job has its learning curve, and it's okay to start with small tasks. Begin by learning from the other groomer and gaining knowledge about dog grooming. While you may not be able to bathe dogs right away, there are other tasks you can do in the meantime, such as cleaning kennels or assisting other groomers. This way, you can still contribute and earn while learning the ropes.

As for the slow day worries, consider using this time to observe and learn more about dog grooming. You can watch other groomers at work, ask questions, and familiarize yourself with the tools and equipment. Additionally, you can take advantage of any downtime to organize your workspace or help out in other areas of the pet store.

Remember, starting a new job is a big step, but you've already shown resilience and determination in overcoming your anxiety. Trust yourself and believe that you have what it takes to succeed. Keep a positive mindset and remind yourself that making mistakes is part of the learning process. Take it one day at a time and focus on the progress you make along the way.

Lastly, don't forget to celebrate your achievements and give yourself credit for taking this step forward. Surround yourself with supportive people who understand and encourage your growth. And remember, if you ever feel overwhelmed or need someone to talk to, reach out to friends, family, or even online communities for support.

Good luck on your first day and in your new career as a dog groomer!
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i feel like wanting to die why do i not have friend i feel soo empty lonely i mean i do have a lot of people i talk to on a daily basis but for some reason i feel the need to always have someone almost all the time with me like if i stay alone for hour i feel lonely it is weird i just wish to be happy i don t want to kill myself

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to acknowledge that feeling lonely and wanting to be in the company of others can be a normal part of human experience. Many people have similar feelings and it doesn't necessarily mean there is something wrong with you. However, if these feelings are causing significant distress or interfering with your daily life, it may be helpful to explore them further.

One suggestion I have is to consider reaching out to a support group or community where you can connect with others who share similar interests or experiences. This can provide an opportunity for you to meet new people and potentially form meaningful connections. Additionally, engaging in activities that align with your interests can help distract from feelings of loneliness and provide a sense of fulfillment.

Another suggestion is to focus on building a strong support network within your existing relationships. Communicate openly with your friends and loved ones about how you feel and let them know that you value their presence in your life. Sometimes, simply expressing our needs and emotions can deepen connections and lead to increased support.

It might also be beneficial to explore ways to cultivate self-compassion and self-care. Engaging in activities that promote self-love and self-nurturing can help improve overall well-being and reduce feelings of loneliness. This could include practicing mindfulness or meditation, journaling, engaging in hobbies that bring you joy, or seeking therapy as a way to process your emotions and develop coping strategies.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help when needed. If you find that these feelings persist or worsen over time, it may be helpful to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide guidance tailored to your specific situation. They can assist you in navigating these emotions and developing healthy coping mechanisms.

Please take care and remember that there are resources available to support you through this difficult time.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i live at home and i love my parent but i m beginning to spiral after an incident month ago i ve been profoundly depressed and stressed out i wa renting but moved back home to save money while trying to get myself back in order especially because my med stopped working i m an only child and my parent have no friend so now that i m back home all they want to do is constantly talk to me i already have poor sleep a it is but it could be am and my dad will shake me awake to talk about a car or his work day or my mom will come in and talk to me about my finance or why i never talk to her about my mental health one time recently i had been woken up so abruptly i could feel my entire nervous system jolt like i had been struck by lighting even thinking about it make my entire body randomly hurt i never get to be alone anymore i try to get alone time but i never get it for more than a couple hour at an time bc of the sleep deprivation i hallucinate now i hear and see thing i honestly wish somthing would happen to me and it would just all end life s so stressful and the little thing aren t fun anymore i hate myself i hate everything i used to love nothing fun anymore what s the fucking point

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone. Dealing with depression and stress can be incredibly challenging, especially when it feels like there's no escape from the sources of your distress.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge how difficult it must be for you to be dealing with a mental health crisis while also living at home. It can be overwhelming to have your personal space invaded and your sleep disrupted, especially when you're already feeling so drained emotionally. It's completely understandable that this situation is taking a toll on your mental well-being.

One suggestion I have is to establish clear boundaries with your parents regarding your personal space and privacy. Communicating openly and honestly with them about how their actions are impacting your mental health may help them understand the importance of giving you time alone. Perhaps you could try scheduling specific times each day or week where you can have uninterrupted personal time? This way, both you and your parents can have something to look forward to and it may alleviate some of the tension.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms to manage your stress and depression can be beneficial. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies or creative outlets, can provide a much-needed break from the negativity you're experiencing. Taking care of yourself physically by exercising regularly and maintaining a balanced diet can also contribute to your overall well-being.

Consider reaching out to friends or other supportive individuals who can offer a listening ear and emotional support. Sometimes talking to someone outside of our immediate family can provide a fresh perspective and a sense of relief. If you don't feel comfortable discussing your mental health with friends, you might want to explore online support groups or communities where you can connect with others who are going through similar experiences.

Lastly, seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor can be incredibly valuable. They can provide guidance and support tailored specifically to your needs. While I'm not a professional, there are many therapists who offer affordable or sliding scale services. You may want to research options in your area or consider seeking support online.

Remember, healing takes time and it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. You deserve support and understanding as you navigate through these difficult emotions. Keep reaching out for help and exploring different strategies until you find what works best for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Connecting with others who share similar interests or experiences can be comforting. Seek out support groups or online communities where you can discuss and process your feelings about being a vegan, or connect with others who understand the challenges of living with chronic conditions. Sharing your thoughts and emotions with people who can relate may provide you with a sense of validation and support.

Lastly, if you're feeling overwhelmed and unable to see the light at the end of the tunnel, reaching out to a mental health professional can be incredibly beneficial. They can provide you with coping strategies, tools to manage stress, and support to help you navigate through this difficult time. Remember, you don't have to face these challenges alone.

Take things one step at a time, focus on self-care, and remember that there is hope for a brighter future.

 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I can understand how difficult it must be for you. It's important to remember that everyone's experiences with mental health are unique, and what may feel overwhelming for you might not be the same for someone else. However, there are some strategies that may help you cope with these symptoms and improve your well-being.

Firstly, it might be helpful to establish a routine or schedule for yourself. This can provide structure and stability, which can be beneficial when dealing with depressive symptoms. Setting small, achievable goals each day can give you a sense of accomplishment and purpose.

Additionally, engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can also be beneficial. It could be something as simple as taking a walk in nature, listening to music, or pursuing a hobby or interest that you enjoy. These activities can help distract your mind from negative thoughts and uplift your mood.

Connecting with supportive people in your life can make a big difference too. While talking to others about your feelings may have been challenging before, reaching out to trusted friends or family members who are understanding and empathetic can provide you with much-needed support. Sharing your experiences with others who have gone through similar struggles might also be helpful, as they can offer insights and coping strategies that have worked for them.

Taking care of your physical health is equally important. Regular exercise, even if it's just a short walk each day, can boost your mood and reduce symptoms of depression. Prioritizing healthy eating habits and getting enough sleep can also contribute to overall well-being.

Lastly, consider seeking professional help from a mental health expert when you feel ready. They can provide you with guidance, support, and potentially a diagnosis that fits your specific situation. Remember, there's no rush to seek professional help, but it can be a valuable resource down the line.

Remember, recovery takes time and patience. It's okay to have ups and downs along the way, and setbacks are a normal part of the process. Be kind to yourself and celebrate even the smallest victories. You deserve support and healing, and I believe in your ability to overcome this difficult period in your life.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and frustrated after this week's events. It sounds like you've been through a lot, from waking up with a low body temperature to being diagnosed with a rare heart condition and gastroenteritis. These experiences can be distressing and it's natural to want to vent your feelings.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that having a problem with your heart doesn't automatically mean you're experiencing emotional difficulties as well. Emotions and physical health are separate entities, and one doesn't necessarily affect the other unless there is a direct connection. It's essential to keep this in mind to avoid creating doubt or unnecessary worry.

Venting your feelings can be helpful in releasing stress and anxiety. It's good that you're able to find moments to express yourself and let your emotions out. Remember, though, that it's important to do so in a healthy and constructive way. Consider finding an outlet where you can safely express your emotions, such as talking to a trusted friend or family member, writing in a journal, or engaging in creative activities like drawing or painting.

In addition to venting, it may also be beneficial for you to focus on self-care during this challenging time. Taking care of yourself physically, mentally, and emotionally can help you cope better with the difficulties you're facing. This might include activities like getting enough restful sleep, eating nutritious meals, staying hydrated, and engaging in regular exercise. It could also involve practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness meditation, to help manage any anxiety or stress you may be experiencing.

Lastly, seeking support from others can make a significant difference. Connecting with people who understand and empathize with your situation can provide comfort and reassurance. Consider reaching out to support groups, either online or in-person, where you can share your experiences and learn from others who have gone through similar challenges. Building a network of supportive individuals can help you feel less alone and provide valuable advice and encouragement.

Remember, it's okay to have a bad week and to vent your feelings. Taking care of yourself, focusing on self-care, and seeking support from others can help you navigate through this difficult time.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone. It's completely understandable to feel like you've changed and don't recognize yourself anymore after experiencing a significant loss. Grief can be incredibly challenging, and it's important to give yourself permission to grieve and process your emotions at your own pace.

When we experience a loss, it's common to question our purpose and the point of living. These questions can feel overwhelming and may lead us to believe that life is meaningless. However, it's important to remember that these thoughts are often a part of the grieving process and can be worked through with time and support.

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking support from loved ones or joining a support group where you can connect with others who have experienced similar losses. Sharing your feelings and experiences with people who understand can provide comfort and validation. Additionally, talking to someone you trust about your thoughts and emotions can help alleviate some of the burden you may be feeling.

Engaging in self-care activities can also be beneficial during this difficult time. Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial. [The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really glad that you reached out and shared what you've been going through. It takes a lot of courage to open up about these things, so kudos to you for that. I can imagine how tough it must be for you to feel isolated and struggling with depression.

Firstly, I want to say that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people experience similar challenges when starting at a new school or in a new environment. It's completely normal to feel unsure and uncertain during such transitions. Remember to be patient with yourself as finding friends sometimes takes time.

When it comes to making social connections, it can be helpful to focus on building meaningful connections rather than just trying to fit in with large groups. Here are a few suggestions that might help:

1. Identify your interests: Engaging in activities or joining clubs related to your hobbies or passions can provide opportunities to meet like-minded individuals who share similar interests. This common ground can make it easier to connect with others and develop friendships.

2. Take initiative: Instead of waiting for conversations to happen, try taking the initiative by approaching others and starting conversations. You never know, they might appreciate your boldness and it could lead to meaningful interactions.

3. Be open and approachable: Smile, maintain eye contact, and show genuine interest in what others have to say. These small gestures can go a long way in making others feel comfortable around you and increase the chances of forming lasting connections.

4. Seek support outside of school: Consider exploring extracurricular activities or communities where you can meet people who share similar experiences or struggles. Support groups or community centers focused on mental health or specific interests can be great places to find understanding and connection.

5. Utilize online platforms: While it's important to engage in real-life interactions, online platforms can also offer opportunities to connect with others who may have faced similar challenges. Online communities or forums centered around your interests or topics like coping with depression can provide a sense of belonging and support.

Remember, building friendships takes time and effort. Don't be too hard on yourself if things don't happen overnight. Keep putting yourself out there, stay positive, and embrace the journey.

As for your comment about feeling like you don't belong or deserve this problem, it's crucial to address these negative thoughts. Remember that everyone has their own unique struggles, and deservingness has nothing to do with it. Depression can affect anyone, regardless of their background or actions. It's important to challenge these negative beliefs and practice self-compassion.

Lastly, while I can't provide professional help, consider reaching out to a mental health expert or counselor who can offer guidance tailored to your specific situation. They can provide you with additional coping strategies and support that may be beneficial for your journey towards healing and finding friendship.

Remember, you're not alone, and there are people who genuinely care about your well-being. Keep reaching out and exploring different avenues for connection. You deserve to have meaningful relationships in your life, and I believe that with time and effort, you will find the support and companionship you're seeking.

Dealing with the loss of things that bring us joy can be particularly challenging, especially when we don't understand why they are disappearing.

Firstly, I want to assure you that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people have similar experiences and struggle with similar emotions. It can be helpful to know that others have faced similar challenges and found ways to cope.

When it comes to your breakdown and your attempts to seek support, it's important to remember that not every interaction will go smoothly. Sometimes, circumstances beyond our control can affect the outcome. However, it's disheartening to hear about your experiences with the hotline. It's crucial to have access to understanding and empathetic listeners during difficult times, and it can be infuriating when that support falls through.

In terms of coping strategies, there are a few techniques you can try. One approach is to focus on mindfulness and grounding exercises. These exercises involve bringing your attention to the present moment and engaging your senses. For example, you can try focusing on the sensation of your breath or the physical sensations of an object in your hand. This can help redirect your thoughts and provide a sense of stability.

Another technique is to engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. While it may be frustrating when those things disappear, it's essential to continue seeking out moments of happiness. This could involve pursuing hobbies, spending time with loved ones, or exploring new interests. Even if the duration of enjoyment is brief, it can still contribute positively to your overall well-being.

Additionally, finding healthy ways to express your emotions can be beneficial. Journaling is a great outlet for venting frustrations and processing emotions. Writing down your thoughts and feelings can provide clarity and release pent-up energy. Regarding the call to the hotline, it's important to remember that not every interaction will go as planned. Sometimes, circumstances beyond our control can affect the outcome. Remember, finding the right coping strategies may take time and experimentation. It's okay to try different techniques and see what works best for you. Lastly, please know that there are people who genuinely care about your well-being and want to help. i m a frequent poster here i ve struggled all my life with these feeling thing seemed like they were getting better i wa genuinely happy and then it got taken away again i live in shitty section housing i wa kicked out several year ago and i ve been struggling to stay afloat since my mother and i recently discussed me moving back home which wa le than ideal she bought a condo and offered it to me she even suggested i get a roommate i wa overjoyed my so could move in my best friend could move it it seemed wonderful and then once i already signed the paper to move out in two month my mother told me to stop looking for a roommate she ha been considering moving into the larger bedroom and taking my kid sister with her leaving me alone in the smaller bedroom with no support and i have no place to argue against this she bought me a new car a an early birthday gift she s paying for me to go through school i m currently struggling to keep my grade up and she s rightfully angry about it my apartment is messy and she s mad about that too rightfully so i am going to lose my privacy and be stuck in the tiny condo with her without support from my so and my best friend my mother is very controlling so i know i won t be able to play video game or talk to my friend in peace it ll just be lecturing do your homework look for a better job etc etc i don t have the motivation for either i barely have motivation to go to my current job she doesn t get that i m so incredibly depressed and suicidal every single fucking day i just got rejected for a better job and now on top of all that i ll be stuck in a confined space with her with no freedom again and i ll probably become babysitter again for the child i pretty much raised for her it s not fair

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot and are facing some difficult challenges right now. It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and overwhelmed. I'm here to offer some guidance and suggestions to help you navigate this situation.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge and validate your emotions. It's completely normal to feel upset and disappointed when things don't go as planned, especially after experiencing a period of happiness. Allow yourself to grieve the loss of your previous living situation and the independence it provided.

When communicating with your mother about these changes, try to approach the conversation from a place of understanding and empathy. Express your feelings and concerns calmly, using "I" statements to avoid sounding accusatory. For example, instead of saying "You're being controlling," you could say "I feel suffocated when I'm not allowed to have my own space."

Consider discussing your feelings openly with your mother and explaining how her actions make you feel. Share specific examples of situations that have caused you distress in the past. By sharing your perspective, she may gain a better understanding of how her actions impact you and be more willing to find compromises that work for both of you.

Additionally, finding ways to maintain your independence within the confines of your new living arrangement can be helpful. You mentioned that you struggle with motivation, which is a common symptom of depression. To combat this, creating a routine and setting small achievable goals can be beneficial. Break down your tasks into manageable steps and reward yourself for completing them. This can help increase your motivation and sense of accomplishment.

Engaging in activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of purpose can also be helpful. Consider pursuing hobbies or interests that allow you to express yourself creatively or engage in physical activity. Finding healthy coping mechanisms such as journaling, practicing mindfulness, or engaging in regular exercise can improve your mood and overall well-being.

Lastly, reaching out for support from friends, family, or support groups can provide you with a sense of belonging and understanding. Sharing your experiences with others who may have gone through similar situations can offer valuable insights and coping strategies.

Remember, navigating these challenges takes time and patience. It's important to be kind to yourself throughout this process. Celebrate small victories and seek professional help if needed. A mental health professional can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Take care of yourself and remember that you're not alone in this journey.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Firstly, try to create a routine for yourself. Even if it's just a simple daily schedule, having something to look forward to can provide a sense of purpose and motivation. Start small by setting achievable goals for the day, such as taking a shower or going for a short walk outside.

Additionally, consider incorporating activities that bring you joy or relaxation into your routine. This could include hobbies, listening to music, reading a book, or practicing mindfulness exercises. Engaging in activities that make you feel good can help boost your mood and motivation.

It may also be helpful to reach out to someone you trust, such as a friend or family member, and let them know what you're going through. Having support from loved ones can make a big difference in how you feel. They can provide encouragement, lend an ear when you need to talk, or even join you in engaging in enjoyable activities.

Remember to be kind to yourself. Self-care is crucial during challenging times. Take care of your physical health by eating nutritious meals, getting enough sleep, and engaging in regular exercise. Additionally, prioritize your mental well-being by practicing self-compassion, challenging negative thoughts, and seeking moments of relaxation.

Lastly, if you haven't already, consider seeking professional help. A mental health therapist or counselor can provide guidance, support, and coping strategies tailored to your specific needs. They can assist you in navigating through this difficult period and help you develop healthier coping mechanisms.

Please remember that recovery takes time and effort, but with the right support and resources, it is possible to overcome this. You deserve to receive the help and care you need.

[Question]
hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly challenging to cope with the loss of loved ones, especially when they occur so close together. It's understandable that your emotions are feeling overwhelmed right now. Here are a few suggestions that may help you find some calm and center yourself:

1. Take deep breaths: When we're anxious or stressed, our breathing tends to become shallow. Focusing on taking slow, deep breaths can help activate your body's relaxation response and bring a sense of calm.

2. Grounding techniques: These exercises can help you stay present and connected to the current moment. One technique involves using your senses to notice five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise can help redirect your focus away from distressing thoughts.

3. Engage in self-care activities: Taking care of yourself physically and emotionally is crucial during this time. Make sure to eat nutritious meals, get enough sleep, and engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This might include hobbies, spending time in nature, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or connecting with supportive friends or family members.

4. Seek support: It's important to lean on others for support during difficult times. Consider reaching out to trusted friends, joining a support group, or seeking therapy. Talking to someone who understands what you're going through can provide comfort and guidance.

5. Write down your feelings: Expressing your emotions through writing can be therapeutic. Consider keeping a journal where you can freely express your thoughts and feelings about the losses you've experienced. This can also serve as a way to reflect on your progress over time.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's normal to have ups and downs along the way. Be patient with yourself and allow yourself to grieve. If you ever feel overwhelmed or in need of immediate assistance, don't hesitate to reach out to a helpline or crisis hotline in your area.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i fell pain on my left chest and on my left back when i looking for an answer on google i feel it s a symptom of heart disease my mother also ha this and a far a i know heart disease can be inherited i didn t dare to go to the doctor because in our family there is a saying that say it s better not to know

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're concerned about the pain you've been experiencing, especially if it's a family concern. It's important to remember that while family history can contribute to certain health conditions, it doesn't necessarily mean that you have heart disease. There are other factors and considerations to take into account as well.

Firstly, it might be helpful to clarify that feeling pain in your chest and back could potentially have various causes, not just heart-related issues. It could be related to muscle strain, digestive problems, or even psychological factors like anxiety. So, it's essential to consider all possibilities before jumping to conclusions.

One suggestion would be to start by gathering more information about your symptoms. Take note of when the pain occurs, how severe it is, and any other accompanying symptoms. This can help provide a clearer picture for yourself and also when discussing with a healthcare professional if you decide to consult one later on.

Additionally, maintaining a healthy lifestyle can be beneficial for your overall well-being. Engaging in regular physical activity, eating a balanced diet, and managing stress levels can positively impact your heart health. While these practices may not prevent existing conditions from progressing, they can certainly support your heart and overall health.

Considering the saying in your family about not wanting to know, it's important to weigh the benefits and drawbacks of seeking knowledge about your health. Understanding the potential benefits of knowing can help you take appropriate steps towards maintaining your well-being. On the other hand, acknowledging the peace of mind that comes with ignorance is also valid. Ultimately, the decision lies with you and what feels right for you personally.

Remember, this guidance is not a substitute for professional advice, but I hope it offers you some suggestions and considerations to take into account. If you feel comfortable doing so, reaching out to a healthcare professional who can assess your symptoms objectively may provide further clarity and support tailored to your specific situation.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I can understand how overwhelming and confusing it must feel. It's great that you've reached out for support, even if it's just online.

Firstly, let's talk about your situation with your best friend. It's clear that you have strong feelings for her, but it seems like she may not reciprocate those feelings. Dealing with unrequited love can be incredibly difficult, and it's completely normal to feel heartbroken and devastated. It's important to remember that your feelings are valid, but sometimes people don't feel the same way we do. This can be really hard to accept, but it's a part of life.

One suggestion I have is to focus on self-care during this challenging time. Take care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally. Engage in activities that bring you joy and help you relax. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time with loved ones, or exploring new interests. Taking care of yourself will not only help you heal but also give you the strength to face whatever challenges come your way.

Additionally, consider talking to someone you trust about your feelings. Sharing your emotions with a close friend or family member can provide comfort and perspective. They may offer advice or share their own experiences, which could help you gain insight and find new ways to cope. Remember, opening up doesn't make you weak—it shows courage and vulnerability.

Regarding your situation with your parents, it's understandable that you want their approval and love. However, it's important to remember that their opinions may not define your worth or potential. Consider focusing on building a strong relationship with them based on mutual respect and understanding. Communication is key here—try expressing yourself openly and honestly, while also being open to listening to their perspective. Sometimes, finding common ground requires effort from both sides.

Lastly, about your plans for the future, it's okay to be uncertain at this moment. Many people go through similar struggles when facing graduation and job hunting. Take some time to reflect on your passions, interests, and goals. Explore different career options and consider seeking guidance from professionals who can provide you with information and resources. Remember, there are many paths to success, and it's never too late to pivot or explore new opportunities.

Remember, I'm here to listen and support you as much as I can. Feel free to reach out anytime.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you had a really distressing experience at the airport and I'm here to offer you guidance and support. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being, so let's go through some steps you can take to ensure that:

1. Firstly, make sure you are in a safe location right now. If you're not, try to find a trusted place where you can gather your thoughts and collect yourself.

2. Consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can provide emotional support during this difficult time. Having someone to talk to and lean on can be incredibly helpful.

3. Take care of yourself physically by getting enough rest, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you comfort and relaxation. Physical self-care can have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

4. It might be beneficial for you to establish a daily routine or schedule to create a sense of stability and predictability in your life. This can help reduce anxiety and provide a sense of control.

5. Exploring coping mechanisms such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness, or engaging in hobbies that bring you joy can also be helpful in managing anxiety and stress.

6. Consider seeking professional help from a mental health expert who can provide specialized guidance and support tailored to your needs. They can assist you in processing your traumatic experience and developing effective coping strategies.

7. In the meantime, try to engage in activities that make you feel grounded and present. Focusing on the here and now can help alleviate anxiety about the past or future.

8. Remember that healing takes time and it's okay to feel anxious and triggered after such a traumatic experience. Be patient with yourself and allow yourself to feel whatever emotions come up.

9. Lastly, if you ever find yourself in a situation where you don't feel safe, don't hesitate to contact the authorities or trusted individuals who can assist you. Safety should always be a priority.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey. Reach out for support whenever you need it and take things one step at a time towards healing and regaining your sense of safety and well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It's really important to reach out and share what you're going through, even if it feels difficult or uncertain whether anyone will respond. You deserve support and understanding, and there are people who can help you.

Firstly, I want to emphasize that you don't have to face this alone. While it may seem like there aren't many resources in your small town, there are still options available to you. Consider reaching out to helplines or crisis hotlines that offer confidential support. They can provide a listening ear and connect you with local services or organizations that can assist you further.

Additionally, consider exploring online communities or forums where individuals who have experienced similar challenges come together. These spaces can offer empathy, guidance, and connections to resources that may be available to you. Remember to prioritize your safety and well-being by using reputable sources and engaging with trusted individuals within these communities.

Another suggestion is to consider seeking professional help from a mental health therapist or counselor. While it may be challenging to access such services in your area, you can explore options like teletherapy or video counseling sessions. These services can provide you with the necessary tools and coping strategies to manage your depression effectively.

In addition to seeking professional help, it's crucial to build a support network around you. Reach out to friends, family members, or even support groups where you can openly discuss your feelings and experiences. Sharing your struggles with others who understand can provide comfort and validation.

Lastly, take care of yourself. Engage in activities that bring you joy and purpose, such as hobbies, exercise, or creative outlets. Surround yourself with positive influences and practice self-care regularly.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey. By taking proactive steps towards seeking help and engaging in self-care, you can find the support and assistance you need. Keep reaching out and stay hopeful – there are people who genuinely care about your well-being and want to help.

i don t feel like myself anymore and i don t think i can be fixed not a day go by where i wish i didn t wake up again i don t know what s wrong and i ve been trying so hard to be better i just can t do it anymore i m so sorry

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone. It's important to remember that everyone has ups and downs in life, and sometimes it can feel overwhelming. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some guidance and suggestions that may help you during this difficult period.

Firstly, it might be helpful to explore any underlying causes or triggers for these feelings. Have there been any recent changes or stressful events in your life? Identifying and understanding these factors can provide some clarity on what you're experiencing.

Additionally, reaching out to a trusted friend or family member can be beneficial. Sharing your thoughts and emotions with someone who cares about you can offer support and reassurance. They may also be able to provide a different perspective or suggest coping strategies that have worked for them in the past.

Engaging in self-care activities is another important aspect of managing your well-being. This could include practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness meditation. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment, such as hobbies or creative outlets, can also contribute to your overall mental and emotional well-being.

Consider seeking professional help if you haven't already done so. A mental health therapist or counselor can provide valuable guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. Lastly, please remember to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. Healing takes time, and setbacks are a normal part of the journey. Celebrate small victories along the way and focus on progress rather than perfection.

im and mo postpartum i don t know if i have ppocd but the intrusive thought are becoming unbearable my baby is healthy and for the most part happy a lot of the time i feel like a shitty mom because i work full time while my boyfriend is at home with the baby and when i get home im too exhausted to clean house or play with my baby i carry so much guilt about other people watching my son on my day off so i can get thing done because i m his mom and i should be able to take care of him and everything else myself tonight he wa losing his sh t bc he wa overtired his screaming made me feel like i wanted to hurt him or myself i would never hurt him but the thought get so loud i can t seem to escape them i wa in a psych hospital last month but it didn t help at all these thought are a constant sometimes i feel like having a baby wa the wrong choice and i ruined my life and the only way to fix my issue is to end it i just feel so alone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure about what you're experiencing postpartum. It can be challenging to navigate these intrusive thoughts while also taking care of your newborn. Remember, you are not alone in feeling this way. Many mothers go through similar experiences and there is support available for you.

Firstly, it's important to prioritize your mental health. Seeking help is a positive step, and I encourage you to continue reaching out for support. In addition to the resources you've already utilized, consider exploring therapy options such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or dialectical behavior therapy (DBT). These therapeutic approaches can provide you with tools to manage distressing thoughts and develop healthier coping mechanisms.

Building a strong support system is crucial during this time. Reach out to friends, family members, or other mothers who have experienced similar challenges. Sharing your feelings and experiences with others who understand can offer validation and emotional support. Additionally, consider joining local or online support groups where you can connect with other mothers facing similar difficulties.

Finding ways to reduce stress and manage exhaustion can also be helpful. Prioritize self-care by scheduling short breaks throughout the day to engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This could include going for a walk, practicing deep breathing exercises, or pursuing hobbies that you enjoy. Creating a realistic schedule that allows for rest and leisure time can contribute to reducing feelings of overwhelm.

Consider discussing your concerns about being a working mother with your partner and loved ones. Open communication can help alleviate some of the guilt you may be feeling. Explore ways to share responsibilities and create a balanced schedule that allows for quality time with your baby without solely relying on exhaustion as the only form of rest.

Lastly, if you find yourself feeling overwhelmed or having thoughts of self-harm, reach out to a helpline or emergency services right away. Remember, there is hope and support available to you. You don't have to face these challenges alone.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

also i can t even look nobody in the eye because of it wtf do i do it s ruining the relationship i have with my family and parent it s just pissing me tf off i went to get a haircut today but walked tf out because i wa too anxious and my anxiety wa high so when i walked in i sat all the way in the back so my barber and other people wouldn t see me because of my dumbass anxiety but how else wa i gon na get a cut if he couldn t see me right so like i said i just walked tf out with my head down n cried when i got home

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of frustration and distress due to your anxiety, particularly when it comes to social situations and interacting with others. It can be really challenging when anxiety starts to impact our daily lives and relationships, so I understand how important it is for you to find ways to manage and overcome these difficulties.

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking support from a trusted friend or family member who can provide a listening ear and understanding. Sometimes just talking about our feelings and experiences can bring relief and help us gain perspective. Additionally, they may be able to offer suggestions or strategies that have worked for them in similar situations.

Another helpful technique that you can try is deep breathing exercises. When you feel anxious or overwhelmed, take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce anxiety symptoms. You can practice this technique anytime and anywhere, even during moments of high anxiety, to help ground yourself and regain control of your emotions.

In addition to these techniques, it might be beneficial for you to gradually expose yourself to situations that make you anxious, such as going to get a haircut. Start by taking small steps, like making an appointment and then bringing a close friend or family member with you for support. Gradually work your way up to facing your fears more independently. Remember to be patient with yourself throughout this process, as overcoming anxiety takes time and effort.

Lastly, finding healthy coping mechanisms to manage stress and anxiety can be incredibly helpful. Engaging in activities that you enjoy and find relaxing, such as hobbies, exercise, or mindfulness practices, can provide a much-needed outlet for your emotions and promote overall well-being.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It may take some trial and error to find the strategies that resonate with you. If you continue to struggle with your anxiety and it significantly impacts your daily life, it could be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized guidance and support.

Take care of yourself and remember that you have the strength to overcome these challenges.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Remember, recovery is a journey, and setbacks are a normal part of the process. It's essential to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this journey. Keep reaching out for support, trying new coping strategies, and prioritizing your well-being. You deserve to heal and live a fulfilling life.

dutifully working a job that doesn t care about my humanity training people to replace me dutifully caring for a pet that make my mental health worse training them a i stress cry dutifully filling out tax for my dead parent emailing lawyer because my sibling won t fulfill their legal obligation dutifully attending counseling with my spouse actively listening to being told my want and need are wrong dutifully laying in bed quietly so a not do disturb anyone else staring at the ceiling through insomnia and intrusive thought understanding that i don t exist i am just a tool for everyone else this is my duty

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you have been taking on a lot of responsibilities and trying to fulfill various obligations in your life. It's commendable that you are diligent and dedicated to your tasks, whether it's working a job that doesn't appreciate your humanity or caring for a pet that affects your mental health negatively.

However, it's important to remember that while duty and responsibility are valuable, they should not come at the expense of your own well-being and self-worth. You deserve to be recognized and valued as an individual with wants and needs, rather than just being seen as a tool for others.

In order to find a better balance between your duties and your own well-being, consider setting boundaries and prioritizing self-care. It might be helpful to schedule regular breaks throughout the day to engage in activities that bring you joy or help you relax. This could include going for short walks, practicing deep breathing exercises, or finding time to pursue hobbies or interests that make you feel fulfilled.

Additionally, communication plays a crucial role in maintaining healthy relationships. When interacting with others, try expressing your feelings and needs openly and honestly. Remember that assertive communication can be beneficial for both parties involved, as it allows you to express yourself effectively while also considering the perspectives and boundaries of others.

If you find it challenging to communicate your wants and needs, practicing assertiveness techniques may be helpful. One technique you can try is using "I" statements to express how you feel and what you need, instead of blaming or accusing others. For example, instead of saying, "You never listen to me," you can say, "I feel unheard when I don't receive your active listening."

Remember, it's essential to take care of your mental health. If you're struggling with intrusive thoughts and insomnia, there are strategies you can explore to help manage these difficulties. Journaling your thoughts and emotions before bed might help clear your mind and provide some relief from intrusive thoughts. Additionally, creating a relaxing bedtime routine that includes activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or listening to calming music can promote better sleep.

Lastly, seeking support from trusted friends or loved ones can be beneficial. Sharing your experiences and feelings with someone who understands and cares about you can provide comfort and validation. It's important to surround yourself with people who appreciate and respect you for who you are.

Remember, finding a balance between duty and self-care is an ongoing process. Be patient with yourself as you navigate through it, and don't hesitate to seek professional help if needed. You deserve to live a life where your humanity is recognized, and your needs are valued.

sorry if this is the wrong subreddit for a long time in my life all i wanted wa to have someone to be there for me a person that could love me back a much i love them back but now that i have it i don t know if it s what i wanted in my past i had suicidal friend that influenced a huge part of my life i begin to realize how stupid living wa and started to question why we live i m losing all my energy slowly and slowly i find myself losing all motivation and having no goal or dream anymore this reddit is my last ditch effort on seeking help from other people i ve already started to distance from everyone around me i know that i can t be the only one that s been or going through this how were you guy able to keep your energy and have a positive outlook on life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you reached out for support on this subreddit. It can be challenging when you find yourself questioning the purpose of life and feeling a lack of motivation and energy. While I'm not an expert, I can offer some suggestions that may help you maintain your energy and have a positive outlook on life.

1. Self-reflection: Take some time to reflect on your values, goals, and dreams. What truly matters to you? What are some short-term and long-term goals you can set for yourself? Understanding your personal values and aspirations can provide a sense of direction and purpose.

2. Seek inspiration: Look for sources of inspiration in your life or in the lives of others. This could be through reading books, listening to podcasts, watching motivational videos, or engaging in activities that align with your interests. Surrounding yourself with positive influences can help shift your perspective and boost your energy levels.

3. Establish routines: Creating daily routines can bring structure and stability to your life, which can positively impact your mood and energy levels. Incorporate activities that you enjoy and that contribute to your overall well-being, such as exercise, hobbies, socializing, or practicing mindfulness and relaxation techniques.

4. Connect with supportive people: Building a strong support network is crucial for maintaining positive energy. Reach out to friends, family members, or even online communities who understand and empathize with what you're going through. Sharing your experiences and feelings with others who have been through similar situations can provide comfort and validation.

5. Practice self-care: Prioritize self-care activities that nourish your mind, body, and soul. Engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as taking walks in nature, practicing hobbies, spending time with loved ones, or pampering yourself with a warm bath or a favorite book.

6. Challenge negative thoughts: Be mindful of negative thoughts and try to replace them with more positive and realistic ones. Cultivating a positive mindset takes time and effort, but it can significantly impact your overall well-being. Consider seeking cognitive-behavioral therapy techniques or practicing gratitude journaling to help shift your perspective.

7. Set realistic goals: Break down your larger goals into smaller, achievable steps. By setting realistic and attainable goals, you can maintain motivation and a sense of accomplishment. Celebrate each small victory along the way, as this can boost your energy and confidence.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to find strategies that resonate with you personally. If you continue to struggle with your current situation, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.

the other hand i have been reading some post on here about how much med helped people i am hoping to hear from some people that have been on any of these medication and what their experience were also people could speak to their experience or have any encouragement or advice for someone just starting out in therapy and potentially medication please reach out if i can add additional context to my situation to help clarity where i am at also i wa reading some other post on this sub about people being tired all of the time i have spent year trying to figure out medically why to no avail i am starting to wondering if my axiety is causing it can anyone speak to any experience or epiphany they have had with this thanks garrison

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've taken the step to seek help for your anxiety, Garrison. Therapy can be a really valuable tool in managing and overcoming anxiety. While I'm not able to provide specific advice or recommendations as a mental health expert, I can offer some general guidance.

When it comes to medication versus therapy, it's important to consider that everyone's journey is different. Medication can be beneficial for some individuals, particularly those with severe or chronic anxiety. It may help reduce symptoms and provide a stable foundation while you work on therapy techniques. However, it's also important to remember that medication is not the only solution and should be considered as part of a comprehensive treatment plan.

Therapy can be an effective standalone treatment or can complement medication. In therapy, you'll have the opportunity to explore the root causes of your anxiety, develop coping strategies, and learn techniques to manage and overcome it. It's a process that takes time, but many people find therapy to be incredibly helpful in addressing their anxiety.

If you decide to pursue medication, it's essential to work closely with a healthcare provider who can monitor your progress and make adjustments if needed. They will consider factors such as the severity of your symptoms, any potential underlying conditions, and your overall health when determining the appropriate medication and dosage. Remember that medication is not one-size-fits-all, so finding the right one may involve some trial and error.

In terms of side effects, it's important to discuss these concerns with your prescriber. They can provide information about potential side effects of the specific medications they recommended (Zoloft or Lexapro) and address any concerns you may have. It's worth noting that not everyone experiences side effects, but it's essential to communicate your concerns openly with your prescriber.

Remember, this is just general guidance, and it's crucial to consult with a mental health professional who can assess your unique situation and provide personalized recommendations. They can help you create a treatment plan tailored to your needs and monitor your progress along the way.

Lastly, Garrison, please keep in mind that I am not a mental health expert, but I encourage you to reach out to others who have experienced similar challenges. Connecting with people who have been through therapy and medication can provide valuable insights and support. You might find it helpful to engage in discussions on support groups or forums where individuals share their experiences and offer encouragement to those starting their anxiety improvement journey.

Take care, and remember that you're not alone in this.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
